To amuse her, and be agreeable in her eyes, seemed all that he\r\ncared for\xe2\x80\x94and Emma, glad to be enlivened, not sorry to be flattered,\r\nwas gay and easy too, and gave him all the friendly encouragement, the\r\nadmission to be gallant, which she had ever given in the first and most\r\nanimating period of their acquaintance; but which now, in her own\r\nestimation, meant nothing, though in the judgment of most people\r\nlooking on it must have had such an appearance as no English word but\r\nflirtation could very well describe. \xe2\x80\x9cMr. Frank Churchill and Miss\r\nWoodhouse flirted together excessively.\xe2\x80\x9d They were laying themselves\r\nopen to that very phrase\xe2\x80\x94and to having it sent off in a letter to Maple\r\nGrove by one lady, to Ireland by another. Not that Emma was gay and\r\nthoughtless from any real felicity; it was rather because she felt less\r\nhappy than she had expected. She laughed because she was disappointed;\r\nand though she liked him for his attentions, and thought them all,\r\nwhether in friendship, admiration, or playfulness, extremely judicious,\r\nthey were not winning back her heart. She still intended him for her\r\nfriend.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow much I am obliged to you,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cfor telling me to come\r\nto-day!\xe2\x80\x94If it had not been for you, I should certainly have lost all\r\nthe happiness of this party. I had quite determined to go away again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, you were very cross; and I do not know what about, except that\r\nyou were too late for the best strawberries. I was a kinder friend than\r\nyou deserved. But you were humble. You begged hard to be commanded to\r\ncome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t say I was cross. I was fatigued. The heat overcame me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is hotter to-day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot to my feelings. I am perfectly comfortable to-day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are comfortable because you are under command.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour command?\xe2\x80\x94Yes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps I intended you to say so, but I meant self-command. You had,\r\nsomehow or other, broken bounds yesterday, and run away from your own\r\nmanagement; but to-day you are got back again\xe2\x80\x94and as I cannot be always\r\nwith you, it is best to believe your temper under your own command\r\nrather than mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt comes to the same thing. I can have no self-command without a\r\nmotive. You order me, whether you speak or not. And you can be always\r\nwith me. You are always with me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDating from three o\xe2\x80\x99clock yesterday. My perpetual influence could not\r\nbegin earlier, or you would not have been so much out of humour\r\nbefore.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThree o\xe2\x80\x99clock yesterday! That is your date. I thought I had seen you\r\nfirst in February.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour gallantry is really unanswerable. But (lowering her voice)\xe2\x80\x94nobody\r\nspeaks except ourselves, and it is rather too much to be talking\r\nnonsense for the entertainment of seven silent people.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say nothing of which I am ashamed,\xe2\x80\x9d replied he, with lively\r\nimpudence. \xe2\x80\x9cI saw you first in February. Let every body on the Hill\r\nhear me if they can. Let my accents swell to Mickleham on one side, and\r\nDorking on the other. I saw you first in February.\xe2\x80\x9d And then\r\nwhispering\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cOur companions are excessively stupid. What shall we do to\r\nrouse them? Any nonsense will serve. They _shall_ talk. Ladies and\r\ngentlemen, I am ordered by Miss Woodhouse (who, wherever she is,\r\npresides) to say, that she desires to know what you are all thinking\r\nof?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSome laughed, and answered good-humouredly. Miss Bates said a great\r\ndeal; Mrs. Elton swelled at the idea of Miss Woodhouse\xe2\x80\x99s presiding; Mr.\r\nKnightley\xe2\x80\x99s answer was the most distinct.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs Miss Woodhouse sure that she would like to hear what we are all\r\nthinking of?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! no, no\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94cried Emma, laughing as carelessly as she could\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cUpon no\r\naccount in the world. It is the very last thing I would stand the brunt\r\nof just now. Let me hear any thing rather than what you are all\r\nthinking of. I will not say quite all. There are one or two, perhaps,\r\n(glancing at Mr. Weston and Harriet,) whose thoughts I might not be\r\nafraid of knowing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a sort of thing,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mrs. Elton emphatically, \xe2\x80\x9cwhich _I_\r\nshould not have thought myself privileged to inquire into. Though,\r\nperhaps, as the _Chaperon_ of the party\xe2\x80\x94_I_ never was in any\r\ncircle\xe2\x80\x94exploring parties\xe2\x80\x94young ladies\xe2\x80\x94married women\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHer mutterings were chiefly to her husband; and he murmured, in reply,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery true, my love, very true. Exactly so, indeed\xe2\x80\x94quite unheard of\xe2\x80\x94but\r\nsome ladies say any thing. Better pass it off as a joke. Every body\r\nknows what is due to _you_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt will not do,\xe2\x80\x9d whispered Frank to Emma; \xe2\x80\x9cthey are most of them\r\naffronted. I will attack them with more address. Ladies and gentlemen\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nam ordered by Miss Woodhouse to say, that she waives her right of\r\nknowing exactly what you may all be thinking of, and only requires\r\nsomething very entertaining from each of you, in a general way. Here\r\nare seven of you, besides myself, (who, she is pleased to say, am very\r\nentertaining already,) and she only demands from each of you either one\r\nthing very clever, be it prose or verse, original or repeated\xe2\x80\x94or two\r\nthings moderately clever\xe2\x80\x94or three things very dull indeed, and she\r\nengages to laugh heartily at them all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! very well,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Miss Bates, \xe2\x80\x9cthen I need not be uneasy.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Three things very dull indeed.\xe2\x80\x99 That will just do for me, you know. I\r\nshall be sure to say three dull things as soon as ever I open my mouth,\r\nshan\xe2\x80\x99t I? (looking round with the most good-humoured dependence on\r\nevery body\xe2\x80\x99s assent)\xe2\x80\x94Do not you all think I shall?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEmma could not resist.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! ma\xe2\x80\x99am, but there may be a difficulty. Pardon me\xe2\x80\x94but you will be\r\nlimited as to number\xe2\x80\x94only three at once.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Bates, deceived by the mock ceremony of her manner, did not\r\nimmediately catch her meaning; but, when it burst on her, it could not\r\nanger, though a slight blush shewed that it could pain her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x94well\xe2\x80\x94to be sure. Yes, I see what she means, (turning to Mr.\r\nKnightley,) and I will try to hold my tongue. I must make myself very\r\ndisagreeable, or she would not have said such a thing to an old\r\nfriend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI like your plan,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mr. Weston. \xe2\x80\x9cAgreed, agreed. I will do my\r\nbest. I am making a conundrum. How will a conundrum reckon?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLow, I am afraid, sir, very low,\xe2\x80\x9d answered his son;\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cbut we shall be\r\nindulgent\xe2\x80\x94especially to any one who leads the way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no,\xe2\x80\x9d said Emma, \xe2\x80\x9cit will not reckon low. A conundrum of Mr.\r\nWeston\xe2\x80\x99s shall clear him and his next neighbour. Come, sir, pray let me\r\nhear it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI doubt its being very clever myself,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Weston. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is too\r\nmuch a matter of fact, but here it is.\xe2\x80\x94What two letters of the alphabet\r\nare there, that express perfection?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat two letters!\xe2\x80\x94express perfection! I am sure I do not know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! you will never guess. You, (to Emma), I am certain, will never\r\nguess.\xe2\x80\x94I will tell you.\xe2\x80\x94M. and A.\xe2\x80\x94Em-ma.\xe2\x80\x94Do you understand?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nUnderstanding and gratification came together. It might be a very\r\nindifferent piece of wit, but Emma found a great deal to laugh at and\r\nenjoy in it\xe2\x80\x94and so did Frank and Harriet.\xe2\x80\x94It did not seem to touch the\r\nrest of the party equally; some looked very stupid about it, and Mr.\r\nKnightley gravely said,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis explains the sort of clever thing that is wanted, and Mr. Weston\r\nhas done very well for himself; but he must have knocked up every body\r\nelse. _Perfection_ should not have come quite so soon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! for myself, I protest I must be excused,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Elton; \xe2\x80\x9c_I_\r\nreally cannot attempt\xe2\x80\x94I am not at all fond of the sort of thing. I had\r\nan acrostic once sent to me upon my own name, which I was not at all\r\npleased with. I knew who it came from. An abominable puppy!\xe2\x80\x94You know\r\nwho I mean (nodding to her husband). These kind of things are very well\r\nat Christmas, when one is sitting round the fire; but quite out of\r\nplace, in my opinion, when one is exploring about the country in\r\nsummer. Miss Woodhouse must excuse me. I am not one of those who have\r\nwitty things at every body\xe2\x80\x99s service. I do not pretend to be a wit. I\r\nhave a great deal of vivacity in my own way, but I really must be\r\nallowed to judge when to speak and when to hold my tongue. Pass us, if\r\nyou please, Mr. Churchill. Pass Mr. E., Knightley, Jane, and myself. We\r\nhave nothing clever to say\xe2\x80\x94not one of us.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, pray pass _me_,\xe2\x80\x9d added her husband, with a sort of sneering\r\nconsciousness; \xe2\x80\x9c_I_ have nothing to say that can entertain Miss\r\nWoodhouse, or any other young lady. An old married man\xe2\x80\x94quite good for\r\nnothing. Shall we walk, Augusta?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith all my heart. I am really tired of exploring so long on one spot.\r\nCome, Jane, take my other arm.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJane declined it, however, and the husband and wife walked off. \xe2\x80\x9cHappy\r\ncouple!\xe2\x80\x9d said Frank Churchill, as soon as they were out of\r\nhearing:\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cHow well they suit one another!\xe2\x80\x94Very lucky\xe2\x80\x94marrying as they\r\ndid, upon an acquaintance formed only in a public place!\xe2\x80\x94They only knew\r\neach other, I think, a few weeks in Bath! Peculiarly lucky!\xe2\x80\x94for as to\r\nany real knowledge of a person\xe2\x80\x99s disposition that Bath, or any public\r\nplace, can give\xe2\x80\x94it is all nothing; there can be no knowledge. It is\r\nonly by seeing women in their own homes, among their own set, just as\r\nthey always are, that you can form any just judgment. Short of that, it\r\nis all guess and luck\xe2\x80\x94and will generally be ill-luck. How many a man\r\nhas committed himself on a short acquaintance, and rued it all the rest\r\nof his life!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Fairfax, who had seldom spoken before, except among her own\r\nconfederates, spoke now.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuch things do occur, undoubtedly.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94She was stopped by a cough. Frank\r\nChurchill turned towards her to listen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou were speaking,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, gravely. She recovered her voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was only going to observe, that though such unfortunate\r\ncircumstances do sometimes occur both to men and women, I cannot\r\nimagine them to be very frequent. A hasty and imprudent attachment may\r\narise\xe2\x80\x94but there is generally time to recover from it afterwards. I\r\nwould be understood to mean, that it can be only weak, irresolute\r\ncharacters, (whose happiness must be always at the mercy of chance,)\r\nwho will suffer an unfortunate acquaintance to be an inconvenience, an\r\noppression for ever.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe made no answer; merely looked, and bowed in submission; and soon\r\nafterwards said, in a lively tone,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I have so little confidence in my own judgment, that whenever I\r\nmarry, I hope some body will chuse my wife for me. Will you? (turning\r\nto Emma.) Will you chuse a wife for me?\xe2\x80\x94I am sure I should like any\r\nbody fixed on by you. You provide for the family, you know, (with a\r\nsmile at his father). Find some body for me. I am in no hurry. Adopt\r\nher, educate her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd make her like myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy all means, if you can.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well. I undertake the commission. You shall have a charming\r\nwife.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe must be very lively, and have hazle eyes. I care for nothing else.\r\nI shall go abroad for a couple of years\xe2\x80\x94and when I return, I shall come\r\nto you for my wife. Remember.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEmma was in no danger of forgetting. It was a commission to touch every\r\nfavourite feeling. Would not Harriet be the very creature described?\r\nHazle eyes excepted, two years more might make her all that he wished.\r\nHe might even have Harriet in his thoughts at the moment; who could\r\nsay? Referring the education to her seemed to imply it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jane to her aunt, \xe2\x80\x9cshall we join Mrs. Elton?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you please, my dear. With all my heart. I am quite ready. I was\r\nready to have gone with her, but this will do just as well. We shall\r\nsoon overtake her. There she is\xe2\x80\x94no, that\xe2\x80\x99s somebody else. That\xe2\x80\x99s one of\r\nthe ladies in the Irish car party, not at all like her.\xe2\x80\x94Well, I\r\ndeclare\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey walked off, followed in half a minute by Mr. Knightley. Mr.\r\nWeston, his son, Emma, and Harriet, only remained; and the young man\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nspirits now rose to a pitch almost unpleasant. Even Emma grew tired at\r\nlast of flattery and merriment, and wished herself rather walking\r\nquietly about with any of the others, or sitting almost alone, and\r\nquite unattended to, in tranquil observation of the beautiful views\r\nbeneath her. The appearance of the servants looking out for them to\r\ngive notice of the carriages was a joyful sight; and even the bustle of\r\ncollecting and preparing to depart, and the solicitude of Mrs. Elton to\r\nhave _her_ carriage first, were gladly endured, in the prospect of the\r\nquiet drive home which was to close the very questionable enjoyments of\r\nthis day of pleasure. Such another scheme, composed of so many\r\nill-assorted people, she hoped never to be betrayed into again.\r\n\r\nWhile waiting for the carriage, she found Mr. Knightley by her side. He\r\nlooked around, as if to see that no one were near, and then said,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEmma, I must once more speak to you as I have been used to do: a\r\nprivilege rather endured than allowed, perhaps, but I must still use\r\nit. I cannot see you acting wrong, without a remonstrance. How could\r\nyou be so unfeeling to Miss Bates? How could you be so insolent in your\r\nwit to a woman of her character, age, and situation?\xe2\x80\x94Emma, I had not\r\nthought it possible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEmma recollected, blushed, was sorry, but tried to laugh it off.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, how could I help saying what I did?\xe2\x80\x94Nobody could have helped it.\r\nIt was not so very bad. I dare say she did not understand me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI assure you she did. She felt your full meaning. She has talked of it\r\nsince. I wish you could have heard how she talked of it\xe2\x80\x94with what\r\ncandour and generosity. I wish you could have heard her honouring your\r\nforbearance, in being able to pay her such attentions, as she was for\r\never receiving from yourself and your father, when her society must be\r\nso irksome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Emma, \xe2\x80\x9cI know there is not a better creature in the world:\r\nbut you must allow, that what is good and what is ridiculous are most\r\nunfortunately blended in her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are blended,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cI acknowledge; and, were she prosperous,\r\nI could allow much for the occasional prevalence of the ridiculous over\r\nthe good. Were she a woman of fortune, I would leave every harmless\r\nabsurdity to take its chance, I would not quarrel with you for any\r\nliberties of manner. Were she your equal in situation\xe2\x80\x94but, Emma,\r\nconsider how far this is from being the case. She is poor; she has sunk\r\nfrom the comforts she was born to; and, if she live to old age, must\r\nprobably sink more. Her situation should secure your compassion. It was\r\nbadly done, indeed! You, whom she had known from an infant, whom she\r\nhad seen grow up from a period when her notice was an honour, to have\r\nyou now, in thoughtless spirits, and the pride of the moment, laugh at\r\nher, humble her\xe2\x80\x94and before her niece, too\xe2\x80\x94and before others, many of\r\nwhom (certainly _some_,) would be entirely guided by _your_ treatment\r\nof her.\xe2\x80\x94This is not pleasant to you, Emma\xe2\x80\x94and it is very far from\r\npleasant to me; but I must, I will,\xe2\x80\x94I will tell you truths while I can;\r\nsatisfied with proving myself your friend by very faithful counsel, and\r\ntrusting that you will some time or other do me greater justice than\r\nyou can do now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhile they talked, they were advancing towards the carriage; it was\r\nready; and, before she could speak again, he had handed her in. He had\r\nmisinterpreted the feelings which had kept her face averted, and her\r\ntongue motionless. They were combined only of anger against herself,\r\nmortification, and deep concern. She had not been able to speak; and,\r\non entering the carriage, sunk back for a moment overcome\xe2\x80\x94then\r\nreproaching herself for having taken no leave, making no\r\nacknowledgment, parting in apparent sullenness, she looked out with\r\nvoice and hand eager to shew a difference; but it was just too late. He\r\nhad turned away, and the horses were in motion. She continued to look\r\nback, but in vain; and soon, with what appeared unusual speed, they\r\nwere half way down the hill, and every thing left far behind. She was\r\nvexed beyond what could have been expressed\xe2\x80\x94almost beyond what she\r\ncould conceal. Never had she felt so agitated, mortified, grieved, at\r\nany circumstance in her life. She was most forcibly struck. The truth\r\nof this representation there was no denying. She felt it at her heart.\r\nHow could she have been so brutal, so cruel to Miss Bates! How could\r\nshe have exposed herself to such ill opinion in any one she valued! And\r\nhow suffer him to leave her without saying one word of gratitude, of\r\nconcurrence, of common kindness!\r\n\r\nTime did not compose her. As she reflected more, she seemed but to feel\r\nit more. She never had been so depressed. Happily it was not necessary\r\nto speak. There was only Harriet, who seemed not in spirits herself,\r\nfagged, and very willing to be silent; and Emma felt the tears running\r\ndown her cheeks almost all the way home, without being at any trouble\r\nto check them, extraordinary as they were.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER VIII\r\n\r\n\r\nThe wretchedness of a scheme to Box Hill was in Emma\xe2\x80\x99s thoughts all the\r\nevening. How it might be considered by the rest of the party, she could\r\nnot tell. They, in their different homes, and their different ways,\r\nmight be looking back on it with pleasure; but in her view it was a\r\nmorning more completely misspent, more totally bare of rational\r\nsatisfaction at the time, and more to be abhorred in recollection, than\r\nany she had ever passed. A whole evening of back-gammon with her\r\nfather, was felicity to it. _There_, indeed, lay real pleasure, for\r\nthere she was giving up the sweetest hours of the twenty-four to his\r\ncomfort; and feeling that, unmerited as might be the degree of his fond\r\naffection and confiding esteem, she could not, in her general conduct,\r\nbe open to any severe reproach. As a daughter, she hoped she was not\r\nwithout a heart. She hoped no one could have said to her, \xe2\x80\x9cHow could\r\nyou be so unfeeling to your father?\xe2\x80\x94I must, I will tell you truths\r\nwhile I can.\xe2\x80\x9d Miss Bates should never again\xe2\x80\x94no, never! If attention, in\r\nfuture, could do away the past, she might hope to be forgiven. She had\r\nbeen often remiss, her conscience told her so; remiss, perhaps, more in\r\nthought than fact; scornful, ungracious. But it should be so no more.\r\nIn the warmth of true contrition, she would call upon her the very next\r\nmorning, and it should be the beginning, on her side, of a regular,\r\nequal, kindly intercourse.\r\n\r\nShe was just as determined when the morrow came, and went early, that\r\nnothing might prevent her. It was not unlikely, she thought, that she\r\nmight see Mr. Knightley in her way; or, perhaps, he might come in while\r\nshe were paying her visit. She had no objection. She would not be\r\nashamed of the appearance of the penitence, so justly and truly hers.\r\nHer eyes were towards Donwell as she walked, but she saw him not.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe ladies were all at home.\xe2\x80\x9d She had never rejoiced at the sound\r\nbefore, nor ever before entered the passage, nor walked up the stairs,\r\nwith any wish of giving pleasure, but in conferring obligation, or of\r\nderiving it, except in subsequent ridicule.\r\n\r\nThere was a bustle on her approach; a good deal of moving and talking.\r\nShe heard Miss Bates\xe2\x80\x99s voice, something was to be done in a hurry; the\r\nmaid looked frightened and awkward; hoped she would be pleased to wait\r\na moment, and then ushered her in too soon. The aunt and niece seemed\r\nboth escaping into the adjoining room. Jane she had a distinct glimpse\r\nof, looking extremely ill; and, before the door had shut them out, she\r\nheard Miss Bates saying, \xe2\x80\x9cWell, my dear, I shall _say_ you are laid\r\ndown upon the bed, and I am sure you are ill enough.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPoor old Mrs. Bates, civil and humble as usual, looked as if she did\r\nnot quite understand what was going on.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am afraid Jane is not very well,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I do not know; they\r\n_tell_ me she is well. I dare say my daughter will be here presently,\r\nMiss Woodhouse. I hope you find a chair. I wish Hetty had not gone. I\r\nam very little able\xe2\x80\x94Have you a chair, ma\xe2\x80\x99am? Do you sit where you like?\r\nI am sure she will be here presently.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEmma seriously hoped she would. She had a moment\xe2\x80\x99s fear of Miss Bates\r\nkeeping away from her. But Miss Bates soon came\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cVery happy and\r\nobliged\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94but Emma\xe2\x80\x99s conscience told her that there was not the same\r\ncheerful volubility as before\xe2\x80\x94less ease of look and manner. A very\r\nfriendly inquiry after Miss Fairfax, she hoped, might lead the way to a\r\nreturn of old feelings. The touch seemed immediate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! Miss Woodhouse, how kind you are!\xe2\x80\x94I suppose you have heard\xe2\x80\x94and are\r\ncome to give us joy. This does not seem much like joy, indeed, in\r\nme\xe2\x80\x94(twinkling away a tear or two)\xe2\x80\x94but it will be very trying for us to\r\npart with her, after having had her so long, and she has a dreadful\r\nheadache just now, writing all the morning:\xe2\x80\x94such long letters, you\r\nknow, to be written to Colonel Campbell, and Mrs. Dixon. \xe2\x80\x98My dear,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid I, \xe2\x80\x98you will blind yourself\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94for tears were in her eyes\r\nperpetually. One cannot wonder, one cannot wonder. It is a great\r\nchange; and though she is amazingly fortunate\xe2\x80\x94such a situation, I\r\nsuppose, as no young woman before ever met with on first going out\xe2\x80\x94do\r\nnot think us ungrateful, Miss Woodhouse, for such surprising good\r\nfortune\xe2\x80\x94(again dispersing her tears)\xe2\x80\x94but, poor dear soul! if you were\r\nto see what a headache she has. When one is in great pain, you know one\r\ncannot feel any blessing quite as it may deserve. She is as low as\r\npossible. To look at her, nobody would think how delighted and happy\r\nshe is to have secured such a situation. You will excuse her not coming\r\nto you\xe2\x80\x94she is not able\xe2\x80\x94she is gone into her own room\xe2\x80\x94I want her to lie\r\ndown upon the bed. \xe2\x80\x98My dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said I, \xe2\x80\x98I shall say you are laid down\r\nupon the bed:\xe2\x80\x99 but, however, she is not; she is walking about the room.\r\nBut, now that she has written her letters, she says she shall soon be\r\nwell. She will be extremely sorry to miss seeing you, Miss Woodhouse,\r\nbut your kindness will excuse her. You were kept waiting at the door\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nwas quite ashamed\xe2\x80\x94but somehow there was a little bustle\xe2\x80\x94for it so\r\nhappened that we had not heard the knock, and till you were on the\r\nstairs, we did not know any body was coming. \xe2\x80\x98It is only Mrs. Cole,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid I, \xe2\x80\x98depend upon it. Nobody else would come so early.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98Well,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nshe, \xe2\x80\x98it must be borne some time or other, and it may as well be now.\xe2\x80\x99\r\nBut then Patty came in, and said it was you. \xe2\x80\x98Oh!\xe2\x80\x99 said I, \xe2\x80\x98it is Miss\r\nWoodhouse: I am sure you will like to see her.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98I can see nobody,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid she; and up she got, and would go away; and that was what made us\r\nkeep you waiting\xe2\x80\x94and extremely sorry and ashamed we were. \xe2\x80\x98If you must\r\ngo, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said I, \xe2\x80\x98you must, and I will say you are laid down upon\r\nthe bed.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEmma was most sincerely interested. Her heart had been long growing\r\nkinder towards Jane; and this picture of her present sufferings acted\r\nas a cure of every former ungenerous suspicion, and left her nothing\r\nbut pity; and the remembrance of the less just and less gentle\r\nsensations of the past, obliged her to admit that Jane might very\r\nnaturally resolve on seeing Mrs. Cole or any other steady friend, when\r\nshe might not bear to see herself. She spoke as she felt, with earnest\r\nregret and solicitude\xe2\x80\x94sincerely wishing that the circumstances which\r\nshe collected from Miss Bates to be now actually determined on, might\r\nbe as much for Miss Fairfax\xe2\x80\x99s advantage and comfort as possible. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\r\nmust be a severe trial to them all. She had understood it was to be\r\ndelayed till Colonel Campbell\xe2\x80\x99s return.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo very kind!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Miss Bates. \xe2\x80\x9cBut you are always kind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was no bearing such an \xe2\x80\x9calways;\xe2\x80\x9d and to break through her\r\ndreadful gratitude, Emma made the direct inquiry of\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere\xe2\x80\x94may I ask?\xe2\x80\x94is Miss Fairfax going?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo a Mrs. Smallridge\xe2\x80\x94charming woman\xe2\x80\x94most superior\xe2\x80\x94to have the charge\r\nof her three little girls\xe2\x80\x94delightful children. Impossible that any\r\nsituation could be more replete with comfort; if we except, perhaps,\r\nMrs. Suckling\xe2\x80\x99s own family, and Mrs. Bragge\xe2\x80\x99s; but Mrs. Smallridge is\r\nintimate with both, and in the very same neighbourhood:\xe2\x80\x94lives only four\r\nmiles from Maple Grove. Jane will be only four miles from Maple Grove.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMrs. Elton, I suppose, has been the person to whom Miss Fairfax owes\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, our good Mrs. Elton. The most indefatigable, true friend. She\r\nwould not take a denial. She would not let Jane say, \xe2\x80\x98No;\xe2\x80\x99 for when\r\nJane first heard of it, (it was the day before yesterday, the very\r\nmorning we were at Donwell,) when Jane first heard of it, she was quite\r\ndecided against accepting the offer, and for the reasons you mention;\r\nexactly as you say, she had made up her mind to close with nothing till\r\nColonel Campbell\xe2\x80\x99s return, and nothing should induce her to enter into\r\nany engagement at present\xe2\x80\x94and so she told Mrs. Elton over and over\r\nagain\xe2\x80\x94and I am sure I had no more idea that she would change her\r\nmind!\xe2\x80\x94but that good Mrs. Elton, whose judgment never fails her, saw\r\nfarther than I did. It is not every body that would have stood out in\r\nsuch a kind way as she did, and refuse to take Jane\xe2\x80\x99s answer; but she\r\npositively declared she would _not_ write any such denial yesterday, as\r\nJane wished her; she would wait\xe2\x80\x94and, sure enough, yesterday evening it\r\nwas all settled that Jane should go. Quite a surprize to me! I had not\r\nthe least idea!\xe2\x80\x94Jane took Mrs. Elton aside, and told her at once, that\r\nupon thinking over the advantages of Mrs. Smallridge\xe2\x80\x99s situation, she\r\nhad come to the resolution of accepting it.\xe2\x80\x94I did not know a word of it\r\ntill it was all settled.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou spent the evening with Mrs. Elton?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, all of us; Mrs. Elton would have us come. It was settled so, upon\r\nthe hill, while we were walking about with Mr. Knightley. \xe2\x80\x98You _must_\r\n_all_ spend your evening with us,\xe2\x80\x99 said she\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98I positively must have you\r\n_all_ come.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Knightley was there too, was he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, not Mr. Knightley; he declined it from the first; and though I\r\nthought he would come, because Mrs. Elton declared she would not let\r\nhim off, he did not;\xe2\x80\x94but my mother, and Jane, and I, were all there,\r\nand a very agreeable evening we had. Such kind friends, you know, Miss\r\nWoodhouse, one must always find agreeable, though every body seemed\r\nrather fagged after the morning\xe2\x80\x99s party. Even pleasure, you know, is\r\nfatiguing\xe2\x80\x94and I cannot say that any of them seemed very much to have\r\nenjoyed it. Jane will be treated with\r\nsuch regard and kindness!\xe2\x80\x94It will be nothing but pleasure, a life of\r\npleasure.\xe2\x80\x94And her salary!\xe2\x80\x94I really cannot venture to name her salary to\r\nyou, Miss Woodhouse. Within a\r\nfortnight. Mrs. Smallridge is in a great hurry. My poor mother does not\r\nknow how to bear it. It was before tea\xe2\x80\x94stay\xe2\x80\x94no, it could not be before tea, because\r\nwe were just going to cards\xe2\x80\x94and yet it was before tea, because I\r\nremember thinking\xe2\x80\x94Oh! no, now I recollect, now I have it; something\r\nhappened before tea, but not that. Mr. Elton was called out of the room\r\nbefore tea, old John Abdy\xe2\x80\x99s son wanted to speak with him. Poor old\r\nJohn, I have a great regard for him; he was clerk to my poor father\r\ntwenty-seven years; and now, poor old man, he is bed-ridden, and very\r\npoorly with the rheumatic gout in his joints\xe2\x80\x94I must go and see him\r\nto-day; and so will Jane, I am sure, if she gets out at all. And poor\r\nJohn\xe2\x80\x99s son came to talk to Mr. Elton about relief from the parish; he\r\nis very well to do himself, you know, being head man at the Crown,\r\nostler, and every thing of that sort, but still he cannot keep his\r\nfather without some help; and so, when Mr. Elton came back, he told us\r\nwhat John ostler had been telling him, and then it came out about the\r\nchaise having been sent to Randalls to take Mr. Frank Churchill to\r\nRichmond. That was what happened before tea. It was after tea that Jane\r\nspoke to Mrs. Elton.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Bates would hardly give Emma time to say how perfectly new this\r\ncircumstance was to her; but as without supposing it possible that she\r\ncould be ignorant of any of the particulars of Mr. Frank Churchill\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ngoing, she proceeded to give them all, it was of no consequence.\r\n\r\nWhat Mr. Elton had learned from the ostler on the subject, being the\r\naccumulation of the ostler\xe2\x80\x99s own knowledge, and the knowledge of the\r\nservants at Randalls, was, that a messenger had come over from Richmond\r\nsoon after the return of the party from Box Hill\xe2\x80\x94which messenger,\r\nhowever, had been no more than was expected; and that Mr. Churchill had\r\nsent his nephew a few lines, containing, upon the whole, a tolerable\r\naccount of Mrs. Churchill, and only wishing him not to delay coming\r\nback beyond the next morning early; but that Mr. Frank Churchill having\r\nresolved to go home directly, without waiting at all, and his horse\r\nseeming to have got a cold, Tom had been sent off immediately for the\r\nCrown chaise, and the ostler had stood out and seen it pass by, the boy\r\ngoing a good pace, and driving very steady.\r\n\r\nThere was nothing in all this either to astonish or interest, and it\r\ncaught Emma\xe2\x80\x99s attention only as it united with the subject which\r\nalready engaged her mind. The contrast between Mrs. Churchill\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nimportance in the world, and Jane Fairfax\xe2\x80\x99s, struck her; one was every\r\nthing, the other nothing\xe2\x80\x94and she sat musing on the difference of\r\nwoman\xe2\x80\x99s destiny, and quite unconscious on what her eyes were fixed,\r\ntill roused by Miss Bates\xe2\x80\x99s saying,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAye, I see what you are thinking of, the pianoforte. What is to become\r\nof that?\xe2\x80\x94Very true. Poor dear Jane was talking of it just now.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98You\r\nmust go,\xe2\x80\x99 said she. \xe2\x80\x98You and I must part. You will have no business\r\nhere.\xe2\x80\x94Let it stay, however,\xe2\x80\x99 said she; \xe2\x80\x98give it houseroom till Colonel\r\nCampbell comes back. I shall talk about it to him; he will settle for\r\nme; he will help me out of all my difficulties.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94And to this day, I do\r\nbelieve, she knows not whether it was his present or his daughter\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNow Emma was obliged to think of the pianoforte; and the remembrance of\r\nall her former fanciful and unfair conjectures was so little pleasing,\r\nthat she soon allowed herself to believe her visit had been long\r\nenough; and, with a repetition of every thing that she could venture to\r\nsay of the good wishes which she really felt, took leave.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER IX\r\n\r\n\r\nEmma\xe2\x80\x99s pensive meditations, as she walked home, were not interrupted;\r\nbut on entering the parlour, she found those who must rouse her. Mr.\r\nKnightley and Harriet had arrived during her absence, and were sitting\r\nwith her father.\xe2\x80\x94Mr. Knightley immediately got up, and in a manner\r\ndecidedly graver than usual, said,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would not go away without seeing you, but I have no time to spare,\r\nand therefore must now be gone directly. I am going to London, to spend\r\na few days with John and Isabella. Have you any thing to send or say,\r\nbesides the \xe2\x80\x98love,\xe2\x80\x99 which nobody carries?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing at all. But is not this a sudden scheme?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes\xe2\x80\x94rather\xe2\x80\x94I have been thinking of it some little time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEmma was sure he had not forgiven her; he looked unlike himself. Time,\r\nhowever, she thought, would tell him that they ought to be friends\r\nagain. While he stood, as if meaning to go, but not going\xe2\x80\x94her father\r\nbegan his inquiries.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my dear, and did you get there safely?\xe2\x80\x94And how did you find my\r\nworthy old friend and her daughter?\xe2\x80\x94I dare say they must have been very\r\nmuch obliged to you for coming. Dear Emma has been to call on Mrs. and\r\nMiss Bates, Mr. Knightley, as I told you before. She is always so\r\nattentive to them!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEmma\xe2\x80\x99s colour was heightened by this unjust praise; and with a smile,\r\nand shake of the head, which spoke much, she looked at Mr.\r\nKnightley.\xe2\x80\x94It seemed as if there were an instantaneous impression in\r\nher favour, as if his eyes received the truth from hers, and all that\r\nhad passed of good in her feelings were at once caught and honoured.\xe2\x80\x94\r\nHe looked at her with a glow of regard. She was warmly gratified\xe2\x80\x94and in\r\nanother moment still more so, by a little movement of more than common\r\nfriendliness on his part.\xe2\x80\x94He took her hand;\xe2\x80\x94whether she had not herself\r\nmade the first motion, she could not say\xe2\x80\x94she might, perhaps, have\r\nrather offered it\xe2\x80\x94but he took her hand, pressed it, and certainly was\r\non the point of carrying it to his lips\xe2\x80\x94when, from some fancy or other,\r\nhe suddenly let it go.\xe2\x80\x94Why he should feel such a scruple, why he should\r\nchange his mind when it was all but done, she could not perceive.\xe2\x80\x94He\r\nwould have judged better, she thought, if he had not stopped.\xe2\x80\x94The\r\nintention, however, was indubitable; and whether it was that his\r\nmanners had in general so little gallantry, or however else it\r\nhappened, but she thought nothing became him more.\xe2\x80\x94It was with him, of\r\nso simple, yet so dignified a nature.\xe2\x80\x94She could not but recall the\r\nattempt with great satisfaction. It spoke such perfect amity.\xe2\x80\x94He left\r\nthem immediately afterwards\xe2\x80\x94gone in a moment. He always moved with the\r\nalertness of a mind which could neither be undecided nor dilatory, but\r\nnow he seemed more sudden than usual in his disappearance.\r\n\r\nEmma could not regret her having gone to Miss Bates, but she wished she\r\nhad left her ten minutes earlier;\xe2\x80\x94it would have been a great pleasure\r\nto talk over Jane Fairfax\xe2\x80\x99s situation with Mr. Knightley.\xe2\x80\x94Neither would\r\nshe regret that he should be going to Brunswick Square, for she knew\r\nhow much his visit would be enjoyed\xe2\x80\x94but it might have happened at a\r\nbetter time\xe2\x80\x94and to have had longer notice of it, would have been\r\npleasanter.\xe2\x80\x94They parted thorough friends, however; she could not be\r\ndeceived as to the meaning of his countenance, and his unfinished\r\ngallantry;\xe2\x80\x94it was all done to assure her that she had fully recovered\r\nhis good opinion.\xe2\x80\x94He had been sitting with them half an hour, she\r\nfound. It was a pity that she had not come back earlier!\r\n\r\nIn the hope of diverting her father\xe2\x80\x99s thoughts from the\r\ndisagreeableness of Mr. Knightley\xe2\x80\x99s going to London; and going so\r\nsuddenly; and going on horseback, which she knew would be all very bad;\r\nEmma communicated her news of Jane Fairfax, and her dependence on the\r\neffect was justified; it supplied a very useful check,\xe2\x80\x94interested,\r\nwithout disturbing him. He had long made up his mind to Jane Fairfax\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ngoing out as governess, and could talk of it cheerfully, but Mr.\r\nKnightley\xe2\x80\x99s going to London had been an unexpected blow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am very glad, indeed, my dear, to hear she is to be so comfortably\r\nsettled. Mrs. Elton is very good-natured and agreeable, and I dare say\r\nher acquaintance are just what they ought to be. I hope it is a dry\r\nsituation, and that her health will be taken good care of. It ought to\r\nbe a first object, as I am sure poor Miss Taylor\xe2\x80\x99s always was with me.\r\nYou know, my dear, she is going to be to this new lady what Miss Taylor\r\nwas to us. And I hope she will be better off in one respect, and not be\r\ninduced to go away after it has been her home so long.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe following day brought news from Richmond to throw every thing else\r\ninto the background. An express arrived at Randalls to announce the\r\ndeath of Mrs. Churchill! Though her nephew had had no particular reason\r\nto hasten back on her account, she had not lived above six-and-thirty\r\nhours after his return. A sudden seizure of a different nature from any\r\nthing foreboded by her general state, had carried her off after a short\r\nstruggle. The great Mrs. Churchill was no more.\r\n\r\nIt was felt as such things must be felt. Every body had a degree of\r\ngravity and sorrow; tenderness towards the departed, solicitude for the\r\nsurviving friends; and, in a reasonable time, curiosity to know where\r\nshe would be buried. Goldsmith tells us, that when lovely woman stoops\r\nto folly, she has nothing to do but to die; and when she stoops to be\r\ndisagreeable, it is equally to be recommended as a clearer of ill-fame.\r\nMrs. Churchill, after being disliked at least twenty-five years, was\r\nnow spoken of with compassionate allowances. In one point she was fully\r\njustified. She had never been admitted before to be seriously ill. The\r\nevent acquitted her of all the fancifulness, and all the selfishness of\r\nimaginary complaints.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor Mrs. Churchill! no doubt she had been suffering a great deal:\r\nmore than any body had ever supposed\xe2\x80\x94and continual pain would try the\r\ntemper. It was a sad event\xe2\x80\x94a great shock\xe2\x80\x94with all her faults, what\r\nwould Mr. Churchill do without her? Mr. Churchill\xe2\x80\x99s loss would be\r\ndreadful indeed. Mr. Churchill would never get over it.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Even Mr.\r\nWeston shook his head, and looked solemn, and said, \xe2\x80\x9cAh! poor woman,\r\nwho would have thought it!\xe2\x80\x9d and resolved, that his mourning should be\r\nas handsome as possible; and his wife sat sighing and moralising over\r\nher broad hems with a commiseration and good sense, true and steady.\r\nHow it would affect Frank was among the earliest thoughts of both. It\r\nwas also a very early speculation with Emma. The character of Mrs.\r\nChurchill, the grief of her husband\xe2\x80\x94her mind glanced over them both\r\nwith awe and compassion\xe2\x80\x94and then rested with lightened feelings on how\r\nFrank might be affected by the event, how benefited, how freed. She saw\r\nin a moment all the possible good. Now, an attachment to Harriet Smith\r\nwould have nothing to encounter. Mr. Churchill, independent of his\r\nwife, was feared by nobody; an easy, guidable man, to be persuaded into\r\nany thing by his nephew. All that remained to be wished was, that the\r\nnephew should form the attachment, as, with all her goodwill in the\r\ncause, Emma could feel no certainty of its being already formed.\r\n\r\nHarriet behaved extremely well on the occasion, with great\r\nself-command. What ever she might feel of brighter hope, she betrayed\r\nnothing. Emma was gratified, to observe such a proof in her of\r\nstrengthened character, and refrained from any allusion that might\r\nendanger its maintenance. They spoke, therefore, of Mrs. Churchill\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndeath with mutual forbearance.\r\n\r\nShort letters from Frank were received at Randalls, communicating all\r\nthat was immediately important of their state and plans. Mr. Churchill\r\nwas better than could be expected; and their first removal, on the\r\ndeparture of the funeral for Yorkshire, was to be to the house of a\r\nvery old friend in Windsor, to whom Mr. Churchill had been promising a\r\nvisit the last ten years. At present, there was nothing to be done for\r\nHarriet; good wishes for the future were all that could yet be possible\r\non Emma\xe2\x80\x99s side.\r\n\r\nIt was a more pressing concern to shew attention to Jane Fairfax, whose\r\nprospects were closing, while Harriet\xe2\x80\x99s opened, and whose engagements\r\nnow allowed of no delay in any one at Highbury, who wished to shew her\r\nkindness\xe2\x80\x94and with Emma it was grown into a first wish. She had scarcely\r\na stronger regret than for her past coldness; and the person, whom she\r\nhad been so many months neglecting, was now the very one on whom she\r\nwould have lavished every distinction of regard or sympathy. She wanted\r\nto be of use to her; wanted to shew a value for her society, and\r\ntestify respect and consideration. She resolved to prevail on her to\r\nspend a day at Hartfield. A note was written to urge it. The invitation\r\nwas refused, and by a verbal message. \xe2\x80\x9cMiss Fairfax was not well enough\r\nto write;\xe2\x80\x9d and when Mr. Perry called at Hartfield, the same morning, it\r\nappeared that she was so much indisposed as to have been visited,\r\nthough against her own consent, by himself, and that she was suffering\r\nunder severe headaches, and a nervous fever to a degree, which made him\r\ndoubt the possibility of her going to Mrs. Smallridge\xe2\x80\x99s at the time\r\nproposed. Her health seemed for the moment completely deranged\xe2\x80\x94appetite\r\nquite gone\xe2\x80\x94and though there were no absolutely alarming symptoms,\r\nnothing touching the pulmonary complaint, which was the standing\r\napprehension of the family, Mr. Perry was uneasy about her. He thought\r\nshe had undertaken more than she was equal to, and that she felt it so\r\nherself, though she would not own it. Her spirits seemed overcome. Her\r\npresent home, he could not but observe, was unfavourable to a nervous\r\ndisorder:\xe2\x80\x94confined always to one room;\xe2\x80\x94he could have wished it\r\notherwise\xe2\x80\x94and her good aunt, though his very old friend, he must\r\nacknowledge to be not the best companion for an invalid of that\r\ndescription. Her care and attention could not be questioned; they were,\r\nin fact, only too great. He very much feared that Miss Fairfax derived\r\nmore evil than good from them. Emma listened with the warmest concern;\r\ngrieved for her more and more, and looked around eager to discover some\r\nway of being useful. To take her\xe2\x80\x94be it only an hour or two\xe2\x80\x94from her\r\naunt, to give her change of air and scene, and quiet rational\r\nconversation, even for an hour or two, might do her good; and the\r\nfollowing morning she wrote again to say, in the most feeling language\r\nshe could command, that she would call for her in the carriage at any\r\nhour that Jane would name\xe2\x80\x94mentioning that she had Mr. Perry\xe2\x80\x99s decided\r\nopinion, in favour of such exercise for his patient. The answer was\r\nonly in this short note:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Fairfax\xe2\x80\x99s compliments and thanks, but is quite unequal to any\r\nexercise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEmma felt that her own note had deserved something better; but it was\r\nimpossible to quarrel with words, whose tremulous inequality shewed\r\nindisposition so plainly, and she thought only of how she might best\r\ncounteract this unwillingness to be seen or assisted. In spite of the\r\nanswer, therefore, she ordered the carriage, and drove to Mrs. Bates\xe2\x80\x99s,\r\nin the hope that Jane would be induced to join her\xe2\x80\x94but it would not\r\ndo;\xe2\x80\x94Miss Bates came to the carriage door, all gratitude, and agreeing\r\nwith her most earnestly in thinking an airing might be of the greatest\r\nservice\xe2\x80\x94and every thing that message could do was tried\xe2\x80\x94but all in\r\nvain. Miss Bates was obliged to return without success; Jane was quite\r\nunpersuadable; the mere proposal of going out seemed to make her\r\nworse.\xe2\x80\x94Emma wished she could have seen her, and tried her own powers;\r\nbut, almost before she could hint the wish, Miss Bates made it appear\r\nthat she had promised her niece on no account to let Miss Woodhouse in.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed, the truth was, that poor dear Jane could not bear to see any\r\nbody\xe2\x80\x94any body at all\xe2\x80\x94Mrs. Elton, indeed, could not be denied\xe2\x80\x94and Mrs.\r\nCole had made such a point\xe2\x80\x94and Mrs. Perry had said so much\xe2\x80\x94but, except\r\nthem, Jane would really see nobody.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEmma did not want to be classed with the Mrs. Eltons, the Mrs. Perrys,\r\nand the Mrs. Coles, who would force themselves anywhere; neither could\r\nshe feel any right of preference herself\xe2\x80\x94she submitted, therefore, and\r\nonly questioned Miss Bates farther as to her niece\xe2\x80\x99s appetite and diet,\r\nwhich she longed to be able to assist. On that subject poor Miss Bates\r\nwas very unhappy, and very communicative; Jane would hardly eat any\r\nthing:\xe2\x80\x94Mr. Perry recommended nourishing food; but every thing they\r\ncould command (and never had any body such good neighbours) was\r\ndistasteful.\r\n\r\nEmma, on reaching home, called the housekeeper directly, to an\r\nexamination of her stores; and some arrowroot of very superior quality\r\nwas speedily despatched to Miss Bates with a most friendly note. In\r\nhalf an hour the arrowroot was returned, with a thousand thanks from\r\nMiss Bates, but \xe2\x80\x9cdear Jane would not be satisfied without its being\r\nsent back; it was a thing she could not take\xe2\x80\x94and, moreover, she\r\ninsisted on her saying, that she was not at all in want of any thing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen Emma afterwards heard that Jane Fairfax had been seen wandering\r\nabout the meadows, at some distance from Highbury, on the afternoon of\r\nthe very day on which she had, under the plea of being unequal to any\r\nexercise, so peremptorily refused to go out with her in the carriage,\r\nshe could have no doubt\xe2\x80\x94putting every thing together\xe2\x80\x94that Jane was\r\nresolved to receive no kindness from _her_. She was sorry, very sorry.\r\nHer heart was grieved for a state which seemed but the more pitiable\r\nfrom this sort of irritation of spirits, inconsistency of action, and\r\ninequality of powers; and it mortified her that she was given so little\r\ncredit for proper feeling, or esteemed so little worthy as a friend:\r\nbut she had the consolation of knowing that her intentions were good,\r\nand of being able to say to herself, that could Mr. Knightley have been\r\nprivy to all her attempts of assisting Jane Fairfax, could he even have\r\nseen into her heart, he would not, on this occasion, have found any\r\nthing to reprove.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER X\r\n\r\n\r\nOne morning, about ten days after Mrs. Churchill\xe2\x80\x99s decease, Emma was\r\ncalled downstairs to Mr. Weston, who \xe2\x80\x9ccould not stay five minutes, and\r\nwanted particularly to speak with her.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94He met her at the parlour-door,\r\nand hardly asking her how she did, in the natural key of his voice,\r\nsunk it immediately, to say, unheard by her father,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan you come to Randalls at any time this morning?\xe2\x80\x94Do, if it be\r\npossible. Mrs. Weston wants to see you. She must see you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs she unwell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, not at all\xe2\x80\x94only a little agitated. She would have ordered the\r\ncarriage, and come to you, but she must see you _alone_, and that you\r\nknow\xe2\x80\x94(nodding towards her father)\xe2\x80\x94Humph!\xe2\x80\x94Can you come?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly. This moment, if you please. It is impossible to refuse what\r\nyou ask in such a way. But what can be the matter?\xe2\x80\x94Is she really not\r\nill?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDepend upon me\xe2\x80\x94but ask no more questions. You will know it all in\r\ntime. The most unaccountable business! But hush, hush!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTo guess what all this meant, was impossible even for Emma. Something\r\nreally important seemed announced by his looks; but, as her friend was\r\nwell, she endeavoured not to be uneasy, and settling it with her\r\nfather, that she would take her walk now, she and Mr. Weston were soon\r\nout of the house together and on their way at a quick pace for\r\nRandalls.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94said Emma, when they were fairly beyond the sweep gates,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cnow\r\nMr. Weston, do let me know what has happened.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he gravely replied.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t ask me. I promised my wife to\r\nleave it all to her. She will break it to you better than I can. Do not\r\nbe impatient, Emma; it will all come out too soon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBreak it to me,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Emma, standing still with terror.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cGood\r\nGod!\xe2\x80\x94Mr. Weston, tell me at once.\xe2\x80\x94Something has happened in Brunswick\r\nSquare. I know it has. Tell me, I charge you tell me this moment what\r\nit is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, indeed you are mistaken.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Weston do not trifle with me.\xe2\x80\x94Consider how many of my dearest\r\nfriends are now in Brunswick Square. Which of them is it?\xe2\x80\x94I charge you\r\nby all that is sacred, not to attempt concealment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUpon my word, Emma.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour word!\xe2\x80\x94why not your honour!\xe2\x80\x94why not say upon your honour, that it\r\nhas nothing to do with any of them? Good Heavens!\xe2\x80\x94What can be to be\r\n_broke_ to me, that does not relate to one of that family?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUpon my honour,\xe2\x80\x9d said he very seriously, \xe2\x80\x9cit does not. It is not in\r\nthe smallest degree connected with any human being of the name of\r\nKnightley.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEmma\xe2\x80\x99s courage returned, and she walked on.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was wrong,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, \xe2\x80\x9cin talking of its being _broke_ to you. I\r\nshould not have used the expression. In fact, it does not concern\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x94it concerns only myself,\xe2\x80\x94that is, we hope.\xe2\x80\x94Humph!\xe2\x80\x94In short, my dear\r\nEmma, there is no occasion to be so uneasy about it. I don\xe2\x80\x99t say that\r\nit is not a disagreeable business\xe2\x80\x94but things might be much worse.\xe2\x80\x94If we\r\nwalk fast, we shall soon be at Randalls.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEmma found that she must wait; and now it required little effort. She\r\nasked no more questions therefore, merely employed her own fancy, and\r\nthat soon pointed out to her the probability of its being some money\r\nconcern\xe2\x80\x94something just come to light, of a disagreeable nature in the\r\ncircumstances of the family,\xe2\x80\x94something which the late event at Richmond\r\nhad brought forward. Her fancy was very active. Half a dozen natural\r\nchildren, perhaps\xe2\x80\x94and poor Frank cut off!\xe2\x80\x94This, though very\r\nundesirable, would be no matter of agony to her. It inspired little\r\nmore than an animating curiosity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho is that gentleman on horseback?\xe2\x80\x9d said she, as they\r\nproceeded\xe2\x80\x94speaking more to assist Mr. Weston in keeping his secret,\r\nthan with any other view.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not know.\xe2\x80\x94One of the Otways.\xe2\x80\x94Not Frank;\xe2\x80\x94it is not Frank, I assure\r\nyou. You will not see him. He is half way to Windsor by this time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas your son been with you, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! yes\xe2\x80\x94did not you know?\xe2\x80\x94Well, well, never mind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFor a moment he was silent; and then added, in a tone much more guarded\r\nand demure,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Frank came over this morning, just to ask us how we did.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey hurried on, and were speedily at Randalls.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nhe, as they entered the room\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI have brought her, and now I hope you\r\nwill soon be better. I shall leave you together. There is no use in\r\ndelay. I shall not be far off, if you want me.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94And Emma distinctly\r\nheard him add, in a lower tone, before he quitted the room,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI have\r\nbeen as good as my word. She has not the least idea.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Weston was looking so ill, and had an air of so much perturbation,\r\nthat Emma\xe2\x80\x99s uneasiness increased; and the moment they were alone, she\r\neagerly said,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it my dear friend? Something of a very unpleasant nature, I\r\nfind, has occurred;\xe2\x80\x94do let me know directly what it is. I have been\r\nwalking all this way in complete suspense. We both abhor suspense. Do\r\nnot let mine continue longer. It will do you good to speak of your\r\ndistress, whatever it may be.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you indeed no idea?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Weston in a trembling voice.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCannot you, my dear Emma\xe2\x80\x94cannot you form a guess as to what you are to\r\nhear?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo far as that it relates to Mr. Frank Churchill, I do guess.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right. It does relate to him, and I will tell you directly;\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n(resuming her work, and seeming resolved against looking up.) \xe2\x80\x9cHe has\r\nbeen here this very morning, on a most extraordinary errand. It is\r\nimpossible to express our surprize. He came to speak to his father on a\r\nsubject,\xe2\x80\x94to announce an attachment\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe stopped to breathe. Emma thought first of herself, and then of\r\nHarriet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMore than an attachment, indeed,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed Mrs. Weston; \xe2\x80\x9can\r\nengagement\xe2\x80\x94a positive engagement.\xe2\x80\x94What will you say, Emma\xe2\x80\x94what will any\r\nbody say, when it is known that Frank Churchill and Miss Fairfax are\r\nengaged;\xe2\x80\x94nay, that they have been long engaged!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEmma even jumped with surprize;\xe2\x80\x94and, horror-struck, exclaimed,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJane Fairfax!\xe2\x80\x94Good God! You are not serious? You do not mean it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou may well be amazed,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Mrs. Weston, still averting her\r\neyes, and talking on with eagerness, that Emma might have time to\r\nrecover\xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cYou may well be amazed. But it is even so. There has been a\r\nsolemn engagement between them ever since October\xe2\x80\x94formed at Weymouth,\r\nand kept a secret from every body. Not a creature knowing it but\r\nthemselves\xe2\x80\x94neither the Campbells, nor her family, nor his.\xe2\x80\x94It is so\r\nwonderful, that though perfectly convinced of the fact, it is yet\r\nalmost incredible to myself. I can hardly believe it.\xe2\x80\x94I thought I knew\r\nhim.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEmma scarcely heard what was said.\xe2\x80\x94Her mind was divided between two\r\nideas\xe2\x80\x94her own former conversations with him about Miss Fairfax; and\r\npoor Harriet;\xe2\x80\x94and for some time she could only exclaim, and require\r\nconfirmation, repeated confirmation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said she at last, trying to recover herself; \xe2\x80\x9cthis is a\r\ncircumstance which I must think of at least half a day, before I can at\r\nall comprehend it. What!\xe2\x80\x94engaged to her all the winter\xe2\x80\x94before either of\r\nthem came to Highbury?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEngaged since October,\xe2\x80\x94secretly engaged.\xe2\x80\x94It has hurt me, Emma, very\r\nmuch. It has hurt his father equally. _Some_ _part_ of his conduct we\r\ncannot excuse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEmma pondered a moment, and then replied, \xe2\x80\x9cI will not pretend _not_ to\r\nunderstand you; and to give you all the relief in my power, be assured\r\nthat no such effect has followed his attentions to me, as you are\r\napprehensive of.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Weston looked up, afraid to believe; but Emma\xe2\x80\x99s countenance was as\r\nsteady as her words.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat you may have less difficulty in believing this boast, of my\r\npresent perfect indifference,\xe2\x80\x9d she continued, \xe2\x80\x9cI will farther tell you,\r\nthat there was a period in the early part of our acquaintance, when I\r\ndid like him, when I was very much disposed to be attached to him\xe2\x80\x94nay,\r\nwas attached\xe2\x80\x94and how it came to cease, is perhaps the wonder.\r\nFortunately, however, it did cease. I have really for some time past,\r\nfor at least these three months, cared nothing about him. You may\r\nbelieve me, Mrs. Weston. This is the simple truth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Weston kissed her with tears of joy; and when she could find\r\nutterance, assured her, that this protestation had done her more good\r\nthan any thing else in the world could do.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Weston will be almost as much relieved as myself,\xe2\x80\x9d said she. \xe2\x80\x9cOn\r\nthis point we have been wretched. It was our darling wish that you\r\nmight be attached to each other\xe2\x80\x94and we were persuaded that it was so.\xe2\x80\x94\r\nImagine what we have been feeling on your account.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have escaped; and that I should escape, may be a matter of grateful\r\nwonder to you and myself. But this does not acquit _him_, Mrs. Weston;\r\nand I must say, that I think him greatly to blame. What right had he to\r\ncome among us with affection and faith engaged, and with manners so\r\n_very_ disengaged? What right had he to endeavour to please, as he\r\ncertainly did\xe2\x80\x94to distinguish any one young woman with persevering\r\nattention, as he certainly did\xe2\x80\x94while he really belonged to another?\xe2\x80\x94How\r\ncould he tell what mischief he might be doing?\xe2\x80\x94How could he tell that\r\nhe might not be making me in love with him?\xe2\x80\x94very wrong, very wrong\r\nindeed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom something that he said, my dear Emma, I rather imagine\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how could _she_ bear such behaviour! Composure with a witness! to\r\nlook on, while repeated attentions were offering to another woman,\r\nbefore her face, and not resent it.\xe2\x80\x94That is a degree of placidity,\r\nwhich I can neither comprehend nor respect.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere were misunderstandings between them, Emma; he said so expressly.\r\nHe had not time to enter into much explanation. He was here only a\r\nquarter of an hour, and in a state of agitation which did not allow the\r\nfull use even of the time he could stay\xe2\x80\x94but that there had been\r\nmisunderstandings he decidedly said. The present crisis, indeed, seemed\r\nto be brought on by them; and those misunderstandings might very\r\npossibly arise from the impropriety of his conduct.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cImpropriety! Oh! Mrs. Weston\xe2\x80\x94it is too calm a censure. Much, much\r\nbeyond impropriety!\xe2\x80\x94It has sunk him, I cannot say how it has sunk him\r\nin my opinion. So unlike what a man should be!\xe2\x80\x94None of that upright\r\nintegrity, that strict adherence to truth and principle, that disdain\r\nof trick and littleness, which a man should display in every\r\ntransaction of his life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, dear Emma, now I must take his part; for though he has been wrong\r\nin this instance, I have known him long enough to answer for his having\r\nmany, very many, good qualities; and\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood God!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Emma, not attending to her.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cMrs. Smallridge, too!\r\nJane actually on the point of going as governess! What could he mean by\r\nsuch horrible indelicacy? To suffer her to engage herself\xe2\x80\x94to suffer her\r\neven to think of such a measure!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe knew nothing about it, Emma. On this article I can fully acquit\r\nhim. It was a private resolution of hers, not communicated to him\xe2\x80\x94or at\r\nleast not communicated in a way to carry conviction.\xe2\x80\x94Till yesterday, I\r\nknow he said he was in the dark as to her plans. They burst on him, I\r\ndo not know how, but by some letter or message\xe2\x80\x94and it was the discovery\r\nof what she was doing, of this very project of hers, which determined\r\nhim to come forward at once, own it all to his uncle, throw himself on\r\nhis kindness, and, in short, put an end to the miserable state of\r\nconcealment that had been carrying on so long.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEmma began to listen better.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am to hear from him soon,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Mrs. Weston. \xe2\x80\x9cHe told me at\r\nparting, that he should soon write; and he spoke in a manner which\r\nseemed to promise me many particulars that could not be given now. Let\r\nus wait, therefore, for this letter. It may bring many extenuations. It\r\nmay make many things intelligible and excusable which now are not to be\r\nunderstood. Don\xe2\x80\x99t let us be severe, don\xe2\x80\x99t let us be in a hurry to\r\ncondemn him. Let us have patience. I must love him; and now that I am\r\nsatisfied on one point, the one material point, I am sincerely anxious\r\nfor its all turning out well, and ready to hope that it may. They must\r\nboth have suffered a great deal under such a system of secresy and\r\nconcealment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_His_ sufferings,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Emma dryly, \xe2\x80\x9cdo not appear to have done him\r\nmuch harm. Well, and how did Mr. Churchill take it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMost favourably for his nephew\xe2\x80\x94gave his consent with scarcely a\r\ndifficulty. Conceive what the events of a week have done in that\r\nfamily! While poor Mrs. Churchill lived, I suppose there could not have\r\nbeen a hope, a chance, a possibility;\xe2\x80\x94but scarcely are her remains at\r\nrest in the family vault, than her husband is persuaded to act exactly\r\nopposite to what she would have required. What a blessing it is, when\r\nundue influence does not survive the grave!\xe2\x80\x94He gave his consent with\r\nvery little persuasion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x9d thought Emma, \xe2\x80\x9che would have done as much for Harriet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis was settled last night, and Frank was off with the light this\r\nmorning. He stopped at Highbury, at the Bates\xe2\x80\x99s, I fancy, some time\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nthen came on hither; but was in such a hurry to get back to his uncle,\r\nto whom he is just now more necessary than ever, that, as I tell you,\r\nhe could stay with us but a quarter of an hour.\xe2\x80\x94He was very much\r\nagitated\xe2\x80\x94very much, indeed\xe2\x80\x94to a degree that made him appear quite a\r\ndifferent creature from any thing I had ever seen him before.\xe2\x80\x94In\r\naddition to all the rest, there had been the shock of finding her so\r\nvery unwell, which he had had no previous suspicion of\xe2\x80\x94and there was\r\nevery appearance of his having been feeling a great deal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd do you really believe the affair to have been carrying on with\r\nsuch perfect secresy?\xe2\x80\x94The Campbells, the Dixons, did none of them know\r\nof the engagement?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEmma could not speak the name of Dixon without a little blush.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNone; not one. He positively said that it had been known to no being\r\nin the world but their two selves.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Emma, \xe2\x80\x9cI suppose we shall gradually grow reconciled to the\r\nidea, and I wish them very happy. But I shall always think it a very\r\nabominable sort of proceeding. What has it been but a system of\r\nhypocrisy and deceit,\xe2\x80\x94espionage, and treachery?\xe2\x80\x94To come among us with\r\nprofessions of openness and simplicity; and such a league in secret to\r\njudge us all!\xe2\x80\x94Here have we been, the whole winter and spring,\r\ncompletely duped, fancying ourselves all on an equal footing of truth\r\nand honour, with two people in the midst of us who may have been\r\ncarrying round, comparing and sitting in judgment on sentiments and\r\nwords that were never meant for both to hear.\xe2\x80\x94They must take the\r\nconsequence, if they have heard each other spoken of in a way not\r\nperfectly agreeable!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am quite easy on that head,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mrs. Weston. \xe2\x80\x9cI am very sure\r\nthat I never said any thing of either to the other, which both might\r\nnot have heard.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are in luck.\xe2\x80\x94Your only blunder was confined to my ear, when you\r\nimagined a certain friend of ours in love with the lady.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue. But as I have always had a thoroughly good opinion of Miss\r\nFairfax, I never could, under any blunder, have spoken ill of her; and\r\nas to speaking ill of him, there I must have been safe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this moment Mr. Weston appeared at a little distance from the\r\nwindow, evidently on the watch. His wife gave him a look which invited\r\nhim in; and, while he was coming round, added, \xe2\x80\x9cNow, dearest Emma, let\r\nme intreat you to say and look every thing that may set his heart at\r\nease, and incline him to be satisfied with the match. Let us make the\r\nbest of it\xe2\x80\x94and, indeed, almost every thing may be fairly said in her\r\nfavour. It is not a connexion to gratify; but if Mr. Churchill does not\r\nfeel that, why should we? and it may be a very fortunate circumstance\r\nfor him, for Frank, I mean, that he should have attached himself to a\r\ngirl of such steadiness of character and good judgment as I have always\r\ngiven her credit for\xe2\x80\x94and still am disposed to give her credit for, in\r\nspite of this one great deviation from the strict rule of right. And\r\nhow much may be said in her situation for even that error!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMuch, indeed!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Emma feelingly. \xe2\x80\x9cIf a woman can ever be excused\r\nfor thinking only of herself, it is in a situation like Jane\r\nFairfax\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x94Of such, one may almost say, that \xe2\x80\x98the world is not their\xe2\x80\x99s,\r\nnor the world\xe2\x80\x99s law.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe met Mr. Weston on his entrance, with a smiling countenance,\r\nexclaiming,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA very pretty trick you have been playing me, upon my word! This was a\r\ndevice, I suppose, to sport with my curiosity, and exercise my talent\r\nof guessing. But you really frightened me. I thought you had lost half\r\nyour property, at least. And here, instead of its being a matter of\r\ncondolence, it turns out to be one of congratulation.\xe2\x80\x94I congratulate\r\nyou, Mr. Weston, with all my heart, on the prospect of having one of\r\nthe most lovely and accomplished young women in England for your\r\ndaughter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA glance or two between him and his wife, convinced him that all was as\r\nright as this speech proclaimed; and its happy effect on his spirits\r\nwas immediate. His air and voice recovered their usual briskness: he\r\nshook her heartily and gratefully by the hand, and entered on the\r\nsubject in a manner to prove, that he now only wanted time and\r\npersuasion to think the engagement no very bad thing. His companions\r\nsuggested only what could palliate imprudence, or smooth objections;\r\nand by the time they had talked it all over together, and he had talked\r\nit all over again with Emma, in their walk back to Hartfield, he was\r\nbecome perfectly reconciled, and not far from thinking it the very best\r\nthing that Frank could possibly have done.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XI\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHarriet, poor Harriet!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Those were the words; in them lay the\r\ntormenting ideas which Emma could not get rid of, and which constituted\r\nthe real misery of the business to her. Frank Churchill had behaved\r\nvery ill by herself\xe2\x80\x94very ill in many ways,\xe2\x80\x94but it was not so much _his_\r\nbehaviour as her _own_, which made her so angry with him. It was the\r\nscrape which he had drawn her into on Harriet\xe2\x80\x99s account, that gave the\r\ndeepest hue to his offence.\xe2\x80\x94Poor Harriet! to be a second time the dupe\r\nof her misconceptions and flattery. Mr. Knightley had spoken\r\nprophetically, when he once said, \xe2\x80\x9cEmma, you have been no friend to\r\nHarriet Smith.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94She was afraid she had done her nothing but\r\ndisservice.\xe2\x80\x94It was true that she had not to charge herself, in this\r\ninstance as in the former, with being the sole and original author of\r\nthe mischief; with having suggested such feelings as might otherwise\r\nnever have entered Harriet\xe2\x80\x99s imagination; for Harriet had acknowledged\r\nher admiration and preference of Frank Churchill before she had ever\r\ngiven her a hint on the subject; but she felt completely guilty of\r\nhaving encouraged what she might have repressed. She might have\r\nprevented the indulgence and increase of such sentiments. Her influence\r\nwould have been enough. And now she was very conscious that she ought\r\nto have prevented them.\xe2\x80\x94She felt that she had been risking her friend\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhappiness on most insufficient grounds. Common sense would have\r\ndirected her to tell Harriet, that she must not allow herself to think\r\nof him, and that there were five hundred chances to one against his\r\never caring for her.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cBut, with common sense,\xe2\x80\x9d she added, \xe2\x80\x9cI am afraid\r\nI have had little to do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe was extremely angry with herself. If she could not have been angry\r\nwith Frank Churchill too, it would have been dreadful.\xe2\x80\x94As for Jane\r\nFairfax, she might at least relieve her feelings from any present\r\nsolicitude on her account. Harriet would be anxiety enough; she need no\r\nlonger be unhappy about Jane, whose troubles and whose ill-health\r\nhaving, of course, the same origin, must be equally under cure.\xe2\x80\x94Her\r\ndays of insignificance and evil were over.\xe2\x80\x94She would soon be well, and\r\nhappy, and prosperous.\xe2\x80\x94Emma could now imagine why her own attentions\r\nhad been slighted. This discovery laid many smaller matters open. No\r\ndoubt it had been from jealousy.\xe2\x80\x94In Jane\xe2\x80\x99s eyes she had been a rival;\r\nand well might any thing she could offer of assistance or regard be\r\nrepulsed. An airing in the Hartfield carriage would have been the rack,\r\nand arrowroot from the Hartfield storeroom must have been poison. She\r\nunderstood it all; and as far as her mind could disengage itself from\r\nthe injustice and selfishness of angry feelings, she acknowledged that\r\nJane Fairfax would have neither elevation nor happiness beyond her\r\ndesert. But poor Harriet was such an engrossing charge! There was\r\nlittle sympathy to be spared for any body else. Emma was sadly fearful\r\nthat this second disappointment would be more severe than the first.\r\nConsidering the very superior claims of the object, it ought; and\r\njudging by its apparently stronger effect on Harriet\xe2\x80\x99s mind, producing\r\nreserve and self-command, it would.\xe2\x80\x94She must communicate the painful\r\ntruth, however, and as soon as possible. An injunction of secresy had\r\nbeen among Mr. Weston\xe2\x80\x99s parting words. \xe2\x80\x9cFor the present, the whole\r\naffair was to be completely a secret. Mr. Churchill had made a point of\r\nit, as a token of respect to the wife he had so very recently lost; and\r\nevery body admitted it to be no more than due decorum.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Emma had\r\npromised; but still Harriet must be excepted. It was her superior duty.\r\n\r\nIn spite of her vexation, she could not help feeling it almost\r\nridiculous, that she should have the very same distressing and delicate\r\noffice to perform by Harriet, which Mrs. Weston had just gone through\r\nby herself. The intelligence, which had been so anxiously announced to\r\nher, she was now to be anxiously announcing to another. Her heart beat\r\nquick on hearing Harriet\xe2\x80\x99s footstep and voice; so, she supposed, had\r\npoor Mrs. Weston felt when _she_ was approaching Randalls. Could the\r\nevent of the disclosure bear an equal resemblance!\xe2\x80\x94But of that,\r\nunfortunately, there could be no chance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Miss Woodhouse!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Harriet, coming eagerly into the room\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cis\r\nnot this the oddest news that ever was?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat news do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d replied Emma, unable to guess, by look or\r\nvoice, whether Harriet could indeed have received any hint.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbout Jane Fairfax. Did you ever hear any thing so strange? Oh!\xe2\x80\x94you\r\nneed not be afraid of owning it to me, for Mr. Weston has told me\r\nhimself. I met him just now. He told me it was to be a great secret;\r\nand, therefore, I should not think of mentioning it to any body but\r\nyou, but he said you knew it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat did Mr. Weston tell you?\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94said Emma, still perplexed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! he told me all about it; that Jane Fairfax and Mr. Frank Churchill\r\nare to be married, and that they have been privately engaged to one\r\nanother this long while. How very odd!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was, indeed, so odd; Harriet\xe2\x80\x99s behaviour was so extremely odd, that\r\nEmma did not know how to understand it. Her character appeared\r\nabsolutely changed. She seemed to propose shewing no agitation, or\r\ndisappointment, or peculiar concern in the discovery. Emma looked at\r\nher, quite unable to speak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHad you any idea,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Harriet, \xe2\x80\x9cof his being in love with her?\xe2\x80\x94You,\r\nperhaps, might.\xe2\x80\x94You (blushing as she spoke) who can see into every\r\nbody\xe2\x80\x99s heart; but nobody else\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUpon my word,\xe2\x80\x9d said Emma, \xe2\x80\x9cI begin to doubt my having any such talent.\r\nCan you seriously ask me, Harriet, whether I imagined him attached to\r\nanother woman at the very time that I was\xe2\x80\x94tacitly, if not\r\nopenly\xe2\x80\x94encouraging you to give way to your own feelings?\xe2\x80\x94I never had\r\nthe slightest suspicion, till within the last hour, of Mr. Frank\r\nChurchill\xe2\x80\x99s having the least regard for Jane Fairfax. You may be very\r\nsure that if I had, I should have cautioned you accordingly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMe!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Harriet, colouring, and astonished. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy should you caution\r\nme?\xe2\x80\x94You do not think I care about Mr. Frank Churchill.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am delighted to hear you speak so stoutly on the subject,\xe2\x80\x9d replied\r\nEmma, smiling; \xe2\x80\x9cbut you do not mean to deny that there was a time\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nnot very distant either\xe2\x80\x94when you gave me reason to understand that you\r\ndid care about him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHim!\xe2\x80\x94never, never.
