I must not quarrel with a spirit of forbearance which has\r\nbeen so richly extended towards myself; but, otherwise, I should loudly\r\nprotest against the share of it which that woman has known.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Jane,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nindeed!\xe2\x80\x94You will observe that I have not yet indulged myself in calling\r\nher by that name, even to you. Think, then, what I must have endured in\r\nhearing it bandied between the Eltons with all the vulgarity of\r\nneedless repetition, and all the insolence of imaginary superiority.\r\nHave patience with me, I shall soon have done.\xe2\x80\x94She closed with this\r\noffer, resolving to break with me entirely, and wrote the next day to\r\ntell me that we never were to meet again.\xe2\x80\x94_She_ _felt_ _the_\r\n_engagement_ _to_ _be_ _a_ _source_ _of_ _repentance_ _and_ _misery_\r\n_to_ _each_: _she_ _dissolved_ _it_.\xe2\x80\x94This letter reached me on the very\r\nmorning of my poor aunt\xe2\x80\x99s death. I answered it within an hour; but from\r\nthe confusion of my mind, and the multiplicity of business falling on\r\nme at once, my answer, instead of being sent with all the many other\r\nletters of that day, was locked up in my writing-desk; and I, trusting\r\nthat I had written enough, though but a few lines, to satisfy her,\r\nremained without any uneasiness.\xe2\x80\x94I was rather disappointed that I did\r\nnot hear from her again speedily; but I made excuses for her, and was\r\ntoo busy, and\xe2\x80\x94may I add?\xe2\x80\x94too cheerful in my views to be captious.\xe2\x80\x94We\r\nremoved to Windsor; and two days afterwards I received a parcel from\r\nher, my own letters all returned!\xe2\x80\x94and a few lines at the same time by\r\nthe post, stating her extreme surprize at not having had the smallest\r\nreply to her last; and adding, that as silence on such a point could\r\nnot be misconstrued, and as it must be equally desirable to both to\r\nhave every subordinate arrangement concluded as soon as possible, she\r\nnow sent me, by a safe conveyance, all my letters, and requested, that\r\nif I could not directly command hers, so as to send them to Highbury\r\nwithin a week, I would forward them after that period to her at\xe2\x80\x94: in\r\nshort, the full direction to Mr. Smallridge\xe2\x80\x99s, near Bristol, stared me\r\nin the face. I knew the name, the place, I knew all about it, and\r\ninstantly saw what she had been doing. It was perfectly accordant with\r\nthat resolution of character which I knew her to possess; and the\r\nsecrecy she had maintained, as to any such design in her former letter,\r\nwas equally descriptive of its anxious delicacy. For the world would\r\nnot she have seemed to threaten me.\xe2\x80\x94Imagine the shock; imagine how,\r\ntill I had actually detected my own blunder, I raved at the blunders of\r\nthe post.\xe2\x80\x94What was to be done?\xe2\x80\x94One thing only.\xe2\x80\x94I must speak to my\r\nuncle. Without his sanction I could not hope to be listened to again.\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nspoke; circumstances were in my favour; the late event had softened\r\naway his pride, and he was, earlier than I could have anticipated,\r\nwholly reconciled and complying; and could say at last, poor man! with\r\na deep sigh, that he wished I might find as much happiness in the\r\nmarriage state as he had done.\xe2\x80\x94I felt that it would be of a different\r\nsort.\xe2\x80\x94Are you disposed to pity me for what I must have suffered in\r\nopening the cause to him, for my suspense while all was at stake?\xe2\x80\x94No;\r\ndo not pity me till I reached Highbury, and saw how ill I had made her.\r\nDo not pity me till I saw her wan, sick looks.\xe2\x80\x94I reached Highbury at\r\nthe time of day when, from my knowledge of their late breakfast hour, I\r\nwas certain of a good chance of finding her alone.\xe2\x80\x94I was not\r\ndisappointed; and at last I was not disappointed either in the object\r\nof my journey. A great deal of very reasonable, very just displeasure I\r\nhad to persuade away. But it is done; we are reconciled, dearer, much\r\ndearer, than ever, and no moment\xe2\x80\x99s uneasiness can ever occur between us\r\nagain. Now, my dear madam, I will release you; but I could not conclude\r\nbefore. A thousand and a thousand thanks for all the kindness you have\r\never shewn me, and ten thousand for the attentions your heart will\r\ndictate towards her.\xe2\x80\x94If you think me in a way to be happier than I\r\ndeserve, I am quite of your opinion.\xe2\x80\x94Miss W. calls me the child of good\r\nfortune. I hope she is right.\xe2\x80\x94In one respect, my good fortune is\r\nundoubted, that of being able to subscribe myself,\r\n\r\nYour obliged and affectionate Son,\r\n\r\nF. C. WESTON CHURCHILL.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XV\r\n\r\n\r\nThis letter must make its way to Emma\xe2\x80\x99s feelings. She was obliged, in\r\nspite of her previous determination to the contrary, to do it all the\r\njustice that Mrs. Weston foretold. As soon as she came to her own name,\r\nit was irresistible; every line relating to herself was interesting,\r\nand almost every line agreeable; and when this charm ceased, the\r\nsubject could still maintain itself, by the natural return of her\r\nformer regard for the writer, and the very strong attraction which any\r\npicture of love must have for her at that moment. She never stopt till\r\nshe had gone through the whole; and though it was impossible not to\r\nfeel that he had been wrong, yet he had been less wrong than she had\r\nsupposed\xe2\x80\x94and he had suffered, and was very sorry\xe2\x80\x94and he was so grateful\r\nto Mrs. Weston, and so much in love with Miss Fairfax, and she was so\r\nhappy herself, that there was no being severe; and could he have\r\nentered the room, she must have shaken hands with him as heartily as\r\never.\r\n\r\nShe thought so well of the letter, that when Mr. Knightley came again,\r\nshe desired him to read it. She was sure of Mrs. Weston\xe2\x80\x99s wishing it to\r\nbe communicated; especially to one, who, like Mr. Knightley, had seen\r\nso much to blame in his conduct.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall be very glad to look it over,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cbut it seems long. I\r\nwill take it home with me at night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut that would not do. Mr. Weston was to call in the evening, and she\r\nmust return it by him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would rather be talking to you,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied; \xe2\x80\x9cbut as it seems a\r\nmatter of justice, it shall be done.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe began\xe2\x80\x94stopping, however, almost directly to say, \xe2\x80\x9cHad I been offered\r\nthe sight of one of this gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s letters to his mother-in-law a few\r\nmonths ago, Emma, it would not have been taken with such indifference.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe proceeded a little farther, reading to himself; and then, with a\r\nsmile, observed, \xe2\x80\x9cHumph! a fine complimentary opening: But it is his\r\nway. One man\xe2\x80\x99s style must not be the rule of another\xe2\x80\x99s. We will not be\r\nsevere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt will be natural for me,\xe2\x80\x9d he added shortly afterwards, \xe2\x80\x9cto speak my\r\nopinion aloud as I read. By doing it, I shall feel that I am near you.\r\nIt will not be so great a loss of time: but if you dislike it\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot at all. I should wish it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Knightley returned to his reading with greater alacrity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe trifles here,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cas to the temptation. He knows he is\r\nwrong, and has nothing rational to urge.\xe2\x80\x94Bad.\xe2\x80\x94He ought not to have\r\nformed the engagement.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98His father\xe2\x80\x99s disposition:\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94he is unjust,\r\nhowever, to his father. Mr. Weston\xe2\x80\x99s sanguine temper was a blessing on\r\nall his upright and honourable exertions; but Mr. Weston earned every\r\npresent comfort before he endeavoured to gain it.\xe2\x80\x94Very true; he did not\r\ncome till Miss Fairfax was here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I have not forgotten,\xe2\x80\x9d said Emma, \xe2\x80\x9chow sure you were that he might\r\nhave come sooner if he would. You pass it over very handsomely\xe2\x80\x94but you\r\nwere perfectly right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was not quite impartial in my judgment, Emma:\xe2\x80\x94but yet, I think\xe2\x80\x94had\r\n_you_ not been in the case\xe2\x80\x94I should still have distrusted him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen he came to Miss Woodhouse, he was obliged to read the whole of it\r\naloud\xe2\x80\x94all that related to her, with a smile; a look; a shake of the\r\nhead; a word or two of assent, or disapprobation; or merely of love, as\r\nthe subject required; concluding, however, seriously, and, after steady\r\nreflection, thus\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery bad\xe2\x80\x94though it might have been worse.\xe2\x80\x94Playing a most dangerous\r\ngame. Too much indebted to the event for his acquittal.\xe2\x80\x94No judge of his\r\nown manners by you.\xe2\x80\x94Always deceived in fact by his own wishes, and\r\nregardless of little besides his own convenience.\xe2\x80\x94Fancying you to have\r\nfathomed his secret. Natural enough!\xe2\x80\x94his own mind full of intrigue,\r\nthat he should suspect it in others.\xe2\x80\x94Mystery; Finesse\xe2\x80\x94how they pervert\r\nthe understanding! My Emma, does not every thing serve to prove more\r\nand more the beauty of truth and sincerity in all our dealings with\r\neach other?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEmma agreed to it, and with a blush of sensibility on Harriet\xe2\x80\x99s\r\naccount, which she could not give any sincere explanation of.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou had better go on,\xe2\x80\x9d said she.\r\n\r\nHe did so, but very soon stopt again to say, \xe2\x80\x9cthe pianoforte! Ah! That\r\nwas the act of a very, very young man, one too young to consider\r\nwhether the inconvenience of it might not very much exceed the\r\npleasure. A boyish scheme, indeed!\xe2\x80\x94I cannot comprehend a man\xe2\x80\x99s wishing\r\nto give a woman any proof of affection which he knows she would rather\r\ndispense with; and he did know that she would have prevented the\r\ninstrument\xe2\x80\x99s coming if she could.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAfter this, he made some progress without any pause. Frank Churchill\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nconfession of having behaved shamefully was the first thing to call for\r\nmore than a word in passing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI perfectly agree with you, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94was then his remark. \xe2\x80\x9cYou did behave\r\nvery shamefully. You never wrote a truer line.\xe2\x80\x9d And having gone through\r\nwhat immediately followed of the basis of their disagreement, and his\r\npersisting to act in direct opposition to Jane Fairfax\xe2\x80\x99s sense of\r\nright, he made a fuller pause to say, \xe2\x80\x9cThis is very bad.\xe2\x80\x94He had induced\r\nher to place herself, for his sake, in a situation of extreme\r\ndifficulty and uneasiness, and it should have been his first object to\r\nprevent her from suffering unnecessarily.\xe2\x80\x94She must have had much more\r\nto contend with, in carrying on the correspondence, than he could. He\r\nshould have respected even unreasonable scruples, had there been such;\r\nbut hers were all reasonable. We must look to her one fault, and\r\nremember that she had done a wrong thing in consenting to the\r\nengagement, to bear that she should have been in such a state of\r\npunishment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEmma knew that he was now getting to the Box Hill party, and grew\r\nuncomfortable. Her own behaviour had been so very improper! She was\r\ndeeply ashamed, and a little afraid of his next look. It was all read,\r\nhowever, steadily, attentively, and without the smallest remark; and,\r\nexcepting one momentary glance at her, instantly withdrawn, in the fear\r\nof giving pain\xe2\x80\x94no remembrance of Box Hill seemed to exist.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is no saying much for the delicacy of our good friends, the\r\nEltons,\xe2\x80\x9d was his next observation.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cHis feelings are natural.\xe2\x80\x94What!\r\nactually resolve to break with him entirely!\xe2\x80\x94She felt the engagement to\r\nbe a source of repentance and misery to each\xe2\x80\x94she dissolved it.\xe2\x80\x94What a\r\nview this gives of her sense of his behaviour!\xe2\x80\x94Well, he must be a most\r\nextraordinary\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, nay, read on.\xe2\x80\x94You will find how very much he suffers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope he does,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mr. Knightley coolly, and resuming the\r\nletter. \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Smallridge!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94What does this mean? What is all this?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe had engaged to go as governess to Mrs. Smallridge\xe2\x80\x99s children\xe2\x80\x94a\r\ndear friend of Mrs. Elton\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x94a neighbour of Maple Grove; and, by the\r\nbye, I wonder how Mrs. Elton bears the disappointment?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay nothing, my dear Emma, while you oblige me to read\xe2\x80\x94not even of\r\nMrs. Elton. Only one page more. I shall soon have done. What a letter\r\nthe man writes!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish you would read it with a kinder spirit towards him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, there _is_ feeling here.\xe2\x80\x94He does seem to have suffered in\r\nfinding her ill.\xe2\x80\x94Certainly, I can have no doubt of his being fond of\r\nher. \xe2\x80\x98Dearer, much dearer than ever.\xe2\x80\x99 I hope he may long continue to\r\nfeel all the value of such a reconciliation.\xe2\x80\x94He is a very liberal\r\nthanker, with his thousands and tens of thousands.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Happier than I\r\ndeserve.\xe2\x80\x99 Come, he knows himself there. \xe2\x80\x98Miss Woodhouse calls me the\r\nchild of good fortune.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94Those were Miss Woodhouse\xe2\x80\x99s words, were they?\xe2\x80\x94\r\nAnd a fine ending\xe2\x80\x94and there is the letter. The child of good fortune!\r\nThat was your name for him, was it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou do not appear so well satisfied with his letter as I am; but still\r\nyou must, at least I hope you must, think the better of him for it. I\r\nhope it does him some service with you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, certainly it does. He has had great faults, faults of\r\ninconsideration and thoughtlessness; and I am very much of his opinion\r\nin thinking him likely to be happier than he deserves: but still as he\r\nis, beyond a doubt, really attached to Miss Fairfax, and will soon, it\r\nmay be hoped, have the advantage of being constantly with her, I am\r\nvery ready to believe his character will improve, and acquire from hers\r\nthe steadiness and delicacy of principle that it wants. And now, let me\r\ntalk to you of something else. I have another person\xe2\x80\x99s interest at\r\npresent so much at heart, that I cannot think any longer about Frank\r\nChurchill. Ever since I left you this morning, Emma, my mind has been\r\nhard at work on one subject.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe subject followed; it was in plain, unaffected, gentlemanlike\r\nEnglish, such as Mr. Knightley used even to the woman he was in love\r\nwith, how to be able to ask her to marry him, without attacking the\r\nhappiness of her father. Emma\xe2\x80\x99s answer was ready at the first word.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhile her dear father lived, any change of condition must be\r\nimpossible for her. She could never quit him.\xe2\x80\x9d Part only of this\r\nanswer, however, was admitted. The impossibility of her quitting her\r\nfather, Mr. Knightley felt as strongly as herself; but the\r\ninadmissibility of any other change, he could not agree to. He had been\r\nthinking it over most deeply, most intently; he had at first hoped to\r\ninduce Mr. Woodhouse to remove with her to Donwell; he had wanted to\r\nbelieve it feasible, but his knowledge of Mr. Woodhouse would not\r\nsuffer him to deceive himself long; and now he confessed his\r\npersuasion, that such a transplantation would be a risk of her father\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncomfort, perhaps even of his life, which must not be hazarded. Mr.\r\nWoodhouse taken from Hartfield!\xe2\x80\x94No, he felt that it ought not to be\r\nattempted. But the plan which had arisen on the sacrifice of this, he\r\ntrusted his dearest Emma would not find in any respect objectionable;\r\nit was, that he should be received at Hartfield; that so long as her\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s happiness\xe2\x80\x94in other words, his life\xe2\x80\x94required Hartfield to\r\ncontinue her home, it should be his likewise.\r\n\r\nOf their all removing to Donwell, Emma had already had her own passing\r\nthoughts. Like him, she had tried the scheme and rejected it; but such\r\nan alternative as this had not occurred to her. She was sensible of all\r\nthe affection it evinced. She felt that, in quitting Donwell, he must\r\nbe sacrificing a great deal of independence of hours and habits; that\r\nin living constantly with her father, and in no house of his own, there\r\nwould be much, very much, to be borne with. She promised to think of\r\nit, and advised him to think of it more; but he was fully convinced,\r\nthat no reflection could alter his wishes or his opinion on the\r\nsubject. He had given it, he could assure her, very long and calm\r\nconsideration; he had been walking away from William Larkins the whole\r\nmorning, to have his thoughts to himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! there is one difficulty unprovided for,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Emma. \xe2\x80\x9cI am sure\r\nWilliam Larkins will not like it. You must get his consent before you\r\nask mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe promised, however, to think of it; and pretty nearly promised,\r\nmoreover, to think of it, with the intention of finding it a very good\r\nscheme.\r\n\r\nIt is remarkable, that Emma, in the many, very many, points of view in\r\nwhich she was now beginning to consider Donwell Abbey, was never struck\r\nwith any sense of injury to her nephew Henry, whose rights as\r\nheir-expectant had formerly been so tenaciously regarded. Think she\r\nmust of the possible difference to the poor little boy; and yet she\r\nonly gave herself a saucy conscious smile about it, and found amusement\r\nin detecting the real cause of that violent dislike of Mr. Knightley\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmarrying Jane Fairfax, or any body else, which at the time she had\r\nwholly imputed to the amiable solicitude of the sister and the aunt.\r\n\r\nThis proposal of his, this plan of marrying and continuing at\r\nHartfield\xe2\x80\x94the more she contemplated it, the more pleasing it became.\r\nHis evils seemed to lessen, her own advantages to increase, their\r\nmutual good to outweigh every drawback. Such a companion for herself in\r\nthe periods of anxiety and cheerlessness before her!\xe2\x80\x94Such a partner in\r\nall those duties and cares to which time must be giving increase of\r\nmelancholy!\r\n\r\nShe would have been too happy but for poor Harriet; but every blessing\r\nof her own seemed to involve and advance the sufferings of her friend,\r\nwho must now be even excluded from Hartfield. The delightful family\r\nparty which Emma was securing for herself, poor Harriet must, in mere\r\ncharitable caution, be kept at a distance from. She would be a loser in\r\nevery way. Emma could not deplore her future absence as any deduction\r\nfrom her own enjoyment. In such a party, Harriet would be rather a dead\r\nweight than otherwise; but for the poor girl herself, it seemed a\r\npeculiarly cruel necessity that was to be placing her in such a state\r\nof unmerited punishment.\r\n\r\nIn time, of course, Mr. Knightley would be forgotten, that is,\r\nsupplanted; but this could not be expected to happen very early. Mr.\r\nKnightley himself would be doing nothing to assist the cure;\xe2\x80\x94not like\r\nMr. Elton. Mr. Knightley, always so kind, so feeling, so truly\r\nconsiderate for every body, would never deserve to be less worshipped\r\nthan now; and it really was too much to hope even of Harriet, that she\r\ncould be in love with more than _three_ men in one year.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XVI\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was a very great relief to Emma to find Harriet as desirous as\r\nherself to avoid a meeting. Their intercourse was painful enough by\r\nletter. How much worse, had they been obliged to meet!\r\n\r\nHarriet expressed herself very much as might be supposed, without\r\nreproaches, or apparent sense of ill-usage; and yet Emma fancied there\r\nwas a something of resentment, a something bordering on it in her\r\nstyle, which increased the desirableness of their being separate.\xe2\x80\x94It\r\nmight be only her own consciousness; but it seemed as if an angel only\r\ncould have been quite without resentment under such a stroke.\r\n\r\nShe had no difficulty in procuring Isabella\xe2\x80\x99s invitation; and she was\r\nfortunate in having a sufficient reason for asking it, without\r\nresorting to invention.\xe2\x80\x94There was a tooth amiss. Harriet really wished,\r\nand had wished some time, to consult a dentist. Mrs. John Knightley was\r\ndelighted to be of use; any thing of ill health was a recommendation to\r\nher\xe2\x80\x94and though not so fond of a dentist as of a Mr. Wingfield, she was\r\nquite eager to have Harriet under her care.\xe2\x80\x94When it was thus settled on\r\nher sister\xe2\x80\x99s side, Emma proposed it to her friend, and found her very\r\npersuadable.\xe2\x80\x94Harriet was to go; she was invited for at least a\r\nfortnight; she was to be conveyed in Mr. Woodhouse\xe2\x80\x99s carriage.\xe2\x80\x94It was\r\nall arranged, it was all completed, and Harriet was safe in Brunswick\r\nSquare.\r\n\r\nNow Emma could, indeed, enjoy Mr. Knightley\xe2\x80\x99s visits; now she could\r\ntalk, and she could listen with true happiness, unchecked by that sense\r\nof injustice, of guilt, of something most painful, which had haunted\r\nher when remembering how disappointed a heart was near her, how much\r\nmight at that moment, and at a little distance, be enduring by the\r\nfeelings which she had led astray herself.\r\n\r\nThe difference of Harriet at Mrs. Goddard\xe2\x80\x99s, or in London, made perhaps\r\nan unreasonable difference in Emma\xe2\x80\x99s sensations; but she could not\r\nthink of her in London without objects of curiosity and employment,\r\nwhich must be averting the past, and carrying her out of herself.\r\n\r\nShe would not allow any other anxiety to succeed directly to the place\r\nin her mind which Harriet had occupied. There was a communication\r\nbefore her, one which _she_ only could be competent to make\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nconfession of her engagement to her father; but she would have nothing\r\nto do with it at present.\xe2\x80\x94She had resolved to defer the disclosure till\r\nMrs. Weston were safe and well. No additional agitation should be\r\nthrown at this period among those she loved\xe2\x80\x94and the evil should not act\r\non herself by anticipation before the appointed time.\xe2\x80\x94A fortnight, at\r\nleast, of leisure and peace of mind, to crown every warmer, but more\r\nagitating, delight, should be hers.\r\n\r\nShe soon resolved, equally as a duty and a pleasure, to employ half an\r\nhour of this holiday of spirits in calling on Miss Fairfax.\xe2\x80\x94She ought\r\nto go\xe2\x80\x94and she was longing to see her; the resemblance of their present\r\nsituations increasing every other motive of goodwill. It would be a\r\n_secret_ satisfaction; but the consciousness of a similarity of\r\nprospect would certainly add to the interest with which she should\r\nattend to any thing Jane might communicate.\r\n\r\nShe went\xe2\x80\x94she had driven once unsuccessfully to the door, but had not\r\nbeen into the house since the morning after Box Hill, when poor Jane\r\nhad been in such distress as had filled her with compassion, though all\r\nthe worst of her sufferings had been unsuspected.\xe2\x80\x94The fear of being\r\nstill unwelcome, determined her, though assured of their being at home,\r\nto wait in the passage, and send up her name.\xe2\x80\x94She heard Patty\r\nannouncing it; but no such bustle succeeded as poor Miss Bates had\r\nbefore made so happily intelligible.\xe2\x80\x94No; she heard nothing but the\r\ninstant reply of, \xe2\x80\x9cBeg her to walk up;\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and a moment afterwards she was\r\nmet on the stairs by Jane herself, coming eagerly forward, as if no\r\nother reception of her were felt sufficient.\xe2\x80\x94Emma had never seen her\r\nlook so well, so lovely, so engaging. There was consciousness,\r\nanimation, and warmth; there was every thing which her countenance or\r\nmanner could ever have wanted.\xe2\x80\x94 She came forward with an offered hand;\r\nand said, in a low, but very feeling tone,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is most kind, indeed!\xe2\x80\x94Miss Woodhouse, it is impossible for me to\r\nexpress\xe2\x80\x94I hope you will believe\xe2\x80\x94Excuse me for being so entirely without\r\nwords.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEmma was gratified, and would soon have shewn no want of words, if the\r\nsound of Mrs. Elton\xe2\x80\x99s voice from the sitting-room had not checked her,\r\nand made it expedient to compress all her friendly and all her\r\ncongratulatory sensations into a very, very earnest shake of the hand.\r\n\r\nMrs. Bates and Mrs. Elton were together. Miss Bates was out, which\r\naccounted for the previous tranquillity. Emma could have wished Mrs.\r\nElton elsewhere; but she was in a humour to have patience with every\r\nbody; and as Mrs. Elton met her with unusual graciousness, she hoped\r\nthe rencontre would do them no harm.\r\n\r\nShe soon believed herself to penetrate Mrs. Elton\xe2\x80\x99s thoughts, and\r\nunderstand why she was, like herself, in happy spirits; it was being in\r\nMiss Fairfax\xe2\x80\x99s confidence, and fancying herself acquainted with what\r\nwas still a secret to other people. Emma saw symptoms of it immediately\r\nin the expression of her face; and while paying her own compliments to\r\nMrs. Bates, and appearing to attend to the good old lady\xe2\x80\x99s replies, she\r\nsaw her with a sort of anxious parade of mystery fold up a letter which\r\nshe had apparently been reading aloud to Miss Fairfax, and return it\r\ninto the purple and gold reticule by her side, saying, with significant\r\nnods,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe can finish this some other time, you know. You and I shall not want\r\nopportunities. And, in fact, you have heard all the essential already.\r\nI only wanted to prove to you that Mrs. S. admits our apology, and is\r\nnot offended. You see how delightfully she writes. Oh! she is a sweet\r\ncreature! You would have doated on her, had you gone.\xe2\x80\x94But not a word\r\nmore. Let us be discreet\xe2\x80\x94quite on our good behaviour.\xe2\x80\x94Hush!\xe2\x80\x94You\r\nremember those lines\xe2\x80\x94I forget the poem at this moment:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor when a lady\xe2\x80\x99s in the case,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know all other things give place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nNow I say, my dear, in _our_ case, for _lady_, read\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94mum! a word to the\r\nwise.\xe2\x80\x94I am in a fine flow of spirits, an\xe2\x80\x99t I? But I want to set your\r\nheart at ease as to Mrs. S.\xe2\x80\x94_My_ representation, you see, has quite\r\nappeased her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd again, on Emma\xe2\x80\x99s merely turning her head to look at Mrs. Bates\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nknitting, she added, in a half whisper,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mentioned no _names_, you will observe.\xe2\x80\x94Oh! no; cautious as a\r\nminister of state. I managed it extremely well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEmma could not doubt. It was a palpable display, repeated on every\r\npossible occasion. When they had all talked a little while in harmony\r\nof the weather and Mrs. Weston, she found herself abruptly addressed\r\nwith,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not you think, Miss Woodhouse, our saucy little friend here is\r\ncharmingly recovered?\xe2\x80\x94Do not you think her cure does Perry the highest\r\ncredit?\xe2\x80\x94(here was a side-glance of great meaning at Jane.) Upon my\r\nword, Perry has restored her in a wonderful short time!\xe2\x80\x94Oh! if you had\r\nseen her, as I did, when she was at the worst!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94And when Mrs. Bates was\r\nsaying something to Emma, whispered farther, \xe2\x80\x9cWe do not say a word of\r\nany _assistance_ that Perry might have; not a word of a certain young\r\nphysician from Windsor.\xe2\x80\x94Oh! no; Perry shall have all the credit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have scarce had the pleasure of seeing you, Miss Woodhouse,\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nshortly afterwards began, \xe2\x80\x9csince the party to Box Hill. Very pleasant\r\nparty. But yet I think there was something wanting. Things did not\r\nseem\xe2\x80\x94that is, there seemed a little cloud upon the spirits of some.\xe2\x80\x94So\r\nit appeared to me at least, but I might be mistaken. However, I think\r\nit answered so far as to tempt one to go again. What say you both to\r\nour collecting the same party, and exploring to Box Hill again, while\r\nthe fine weather lasts?\xe2\x80\x94It must be the same party, you know, quite the\r\nsame party, not _one_ exception.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSoon after this Miss Bates came in, and Emma could not help being\r\ndiverted by the perplexity of her first answer to herself, resulting,\r\nshe supposed, from doubt of what might be said, and impatience to say\r\nevery thing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you, dear Miss Woodhouse, you are all kindness.\xe2\x80\x94It is impossible\r\nto say\xe2\x80\x94Yes, indeed, I quite understand\xe2\x80\x94dearest Jane\xe2\x80\x99s prospects\xe2\x80\x94that\r\nis, I do not mean.\xe2\x80\x94But she is charmingly recovered.\xe2\x80\x94How is Mr.\r\nWoodhouse?\xe2\x80\x94I am so glad.\xe2\x80\x94Quite out of my power.\xe2\x80\x94Such a happy little\r\ncircle as you find us here.\xe2\x80\x94Yes, indeed.\xe2\x80\x94Charming young man!\xe2\x80\x94that is\xe2\x80\x94so\r\nvery friendly; I mean good Mr. Perry!\xe2\x80\x94such attention to Jane!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94And from\r\nher great, her more than commonly thankful delight towards Mrs. Elton\r\nfor being there, Emma guessed that there had been a little show of\r\nresentment towards Jane, from the vicarage quarter, which was now\r\ngraciously overcome.\xe2\x80\x94After a few whispers, indeed, which placed it\r\nbeyond a guess, Mrs. Elton, speaking louder, said,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, here I am, my good friend; and here I have been so long, that\r\nanywhere else I should think it necessary to apologise; but, the truth\r\nis, that I am waiting for my lord and master. He promised to join me\r\nhere, and pay his respects to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! are we to have the pleasure of a call from Mr. Elton?\xe2\x80\x94That will\r\nbe a favour indeed! for I know gentlemen do not like morning visits,\r\nand Mr. Elton\xe2\x80\x99s time is so engaged.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUpon my word it is, Miss Bates.\xe2\x80\x94He really is engaged from morning to\r\nnight.\xe2\x80\x94There is no end of people\xe2\x80\x99s coming to him, on some pretence or\r\nother.\xe2\x80\x94The magistrates, and overseers, and churchwardens, are always\r\nwanting his opinion. They seem not able to do any thing without\r\nhim.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Upon my word, Mr. E.,\xe2\x80\x99 I often say, \xe2\x80\x98rather you than I.\xe2\x80\x94I do not\r\nknow what would become of my crayons and my instrument, if I had half\r\nso many applicants.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94Bad enough as it is, for I absolutely neglect them\r\nboth to an unpardonable degree.\xe2\x80\x94I believe I have not played a bar this\r\nfortnight.\xe2\x80\x94However, he is coming, I assure you: yes, indeed, on purpose\r\nto wait on you all.\xe2\x80\x9d And putting up her hand to screen her words from\r\nEmma\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cA congratulatory visit, you know.\xe2\x80\x94Oh! yes, quite indispensable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Bates looked about her, so happily\xe2\x80\x94!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe promised to come to me as soon as he could disengage himself from\r\nKnightley; but he and Knightley are shut up together in deep\r\nconsultation.\xe2\x80\x94Mr. E. is Knightley\xe2\x80\x99s right hand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEmma would not have smiled for the world, and only said, \xe2\x80\x9cIs Mr. Elton\r\ngone on foot to Donwell?\xe2\x80\x94He will have a hot walk.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! no, it is a meeting at the Crown, a regular meeting. Weston and\r\nCole will be there too; but one is apt to speak only of those who\r\nlead.\xe2\x80\x94I fancy Mr. E. and Knightley have every thing their own way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave not you mistaken the day?\xe2\x80\x9d said Emma. \xe2\x80\x9cI am almost certain that\r\nthe meeting at the Crown is not till to-morrow.\xe2\x80\x94Mr. Knightley was at\r\nHartfield yesterday, and spoke of it as for Saturday.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! no, the meeting is certainly to-day,\xe2\x80\x9d was the abrupt answer, which\r\ndenoted the impossibility of any blunder on Mrs. Elton\xe2\x80\x99s side.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI do\r\nbelieve,\xe2\x80\x9d she continued, \xe2\x80\x9cthis is the most troublesome parish that ever\r\nwas. We never heard of such things at Maple Grove.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour parish there was small,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jane.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUpon my word, my dear, I do not know, for I never heard the subject\r\ntalked of.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut it is proved by the smallness of the school, which I have heard\r\nyou speak of, as under the patronage of your sister and Mrs. Bragge;\r\nthe only school, and not more than five-and-twenty children.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! you clever creature, that\xe2\x80\x99s very true. What a thinking brain you\r\nhave! I say, Jane, what a perfect character you and I should make, if\r\nwe could be shaken together. My liveliness and your solidity would\r\nproduce perfection.\xe2\x80\x94Not that I presume to insinuate, however, that\r\n_some_ people may not think _you_ perfection already.\xe2\x80\x94But hush!\xe2\x80\x94not a\r\nword, if you please.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt seemed an unnecessary caution; Jane was wanting to give her words,\r\nnot to Mrs. Elton, but to Miss Woodhouse, as the latter plainly saw.\r\nThe wish of distinguishing her, as far as civility permitted, was very\r\nevident, though it could not often proceed beyond a look.\r\n\r\nMr. Elton made his appearance. His lady greeted him with some of her\r\nsparkling vivacity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery pretty, sir, upon my word; to send me on here, to be an\r\nencumbrance to my friends, so long before you vouchsafe to come!\xe2\x80\x94But\r\nyou knew what a dutiful creature you had to deal with. You knew I\r\nshould not stir till my lord and master appeared.\xe2\x80\x94Here have I been\r\nsitting this hour, giving these young ladies a sample of true conjugal\r\nobedience\xe2\x80\x94for who can say, you know, how soon it may be wanted?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Elton was so hot and tired, that all this wit seemed thrown away.\r\nHis civilities to the other ladies must be paid; but his subsequent\r\nobject was to lament over himself for the heat he was suffering, and\r\nthe walk he had had for nothing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen I got to Donwell,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cKnightley could not be found. Very\r\nodd! very unaccountable! after the note I sent him this morning, and\r\nthe message he returned, that he should certainly be at home till one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDonwell!\xe2\x80\x9d cried his wife.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Mr. E., you have not been to\r\nDonwell!\xe2\x80\x94You mean the Crown; you come from the meeting at the Crown.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, that\xe2\x80\x99s to-morrow; and I particularly wanted to see Knightley\r\nto-day on that very account.\xe2\x80\x94Such a dreadful broiling morning!\xe2\x80\x94I went\r\nover the fields too\xe2\x80\x94(speaking in a tone of great ill-usage,) which made\r\nit so much the worse. And then not to find him at home! I assure you I\r\nam not at all pleased. And no apology left, no message for me. The\r\nhousekeeper declared she knew nothing of my being expected.\xe2\x80\x94Very\r\nextraordinary!\xe2\x80\x94And nobody knew at all which way he was gone. Perhaps to\r\nHartfield, perhaps to the Abbey Mill, perhaps into his woods.\xe2\x80\x94Miss\r\nWoodhouse, this is not like our friend Knightley!\xe2\x80\x94Can you explain it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEmma amused herself by protesting that it was very extraordinary,\r\nindeed, and that she had not a syllable to say for him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot imagine,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Elton, (feeling the indignity as a wife\r\nought to do,) \xe2\x80\x9cI cannot imagine how he could do such a thing by you, of\r\nall people in the world! The very last person whom one should expect to\r\nbe forgotten!\xe2\x80\x94My dear Mr. E., he must have left a message for you, I am\r\nsure he must.\xe2\x80\x94Not even Knightley could be so very eccentric;\xe2\x80\x94and his\r\nservants forgot it. Depend upon it, that was the case: and very likely\r\nto happen with the Donwell servants, who are all, I have often\r\nobserved, extremely awkward and remiss.\xe2\x80\x94I am sure I would not have such\r\na creature as his Harry stand at our sideboard for any consideration.\r\nAnd as for Mrs. Hodges, Wright holds her very cheap indeed.\xe2\x80\x94She\r\npromised Wright a receipt, and never sent it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI met William Larkins,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Mr. Elton, \xe2\x80\x9cas I got near the house,\r\nand he told me I should not find his master at home, but I did not\r\nbelieve him.\xe2\x80\x94William seemed rather out of humour. He did not know what\r\nwas come to his master lately, he said, but he could hardly ever get\r\nthe speech of him. I have nothing to do with William\xe2\x80\x99s wants, but it\r\nreally is of very great importance that _I_ should see Knightley\r\nto-day; and it becomes a matter, therefore, of very serious\r\ninconvenience that I should have had this hot walk to no purpose.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEmma felt that she could not do better than go home directly. In all\r\nprobability she was at this very time waited for there; and Mr.\r\nKnightley might be preserved from sinking deeper in aggression towards\r\nMr. Elton, if not towards William Larkins.\r\n\r\nShe was pleased, on taking leave, to find Miss Fairfax determined to\r\nattend her out of the room, to go with her even downstairs; it gave her\r\nan opportunity which she immediately made use of, to say,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is as well, perhaps, that I have not had the possibility. Had you\r\nnot been surrounded by other friends, I might have been tempted to\r\nintroduce a subject, to ask questions, to speak more openly than might\r\nhave been strictly correct.\xe2\x80\x94I feel that I should certainly have been\r\nimpertinent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Jane, with a blush and an hesitation which Emma thought\r\ninfinitely more becoming to her than all the elegance of all her usual\r\ncomposure\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cthere would have been no danger. The danger would have been\r\nof my wearying you. You could not have gratified me more than by\r\nexpressing an interest\xe2\x80\x94. Indeed, Miss Woodhouse, (speaking more\r\ncollectedly,) with the consciousness which I have of misconduct, very\r\ngreat misconduct, it is particularly consoling to me to know that those\r\nof my friends, whose good opinion is most worth preserving, are not\r\ndisgusted to such a degree as to\xe2\x80\x94I have not time for half that I could\r\nwish to say. I long to make apologies, excuses, to urge something for\r\nmyself. I feel it so very due. But, unfortunately\xe2\x80\x94in short, if your\r\ncompassion does not stand my friend\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! you are too scrupulous, indeed you are,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Emma warmly, and\r\ntaking her hand. \xe2\x80\x9cYou owe me no apologies; and every body to whom you\r\nmight be supposed to owe them, is so perfectly satisfied, so delighted\r\neven\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are very kind, but I know what my manners were to you.\xe2\x80\x94So cold and\r\nartificial!\xe2\x80\x94I had always a part to act.\xe2\x80\x94It was a life of deceit!\xe2\x80\x94I know\r\nthat I must have disgusted you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPray say no more. I feel that all the apologies should be on my side.\r\nLet us forgive each other at once. We must do whatever is to be done\r\nquickest, and I think our feelings will lose no time there. I hope you\r\nhave pleasant accounts from Windsor?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the next news, I suppose, will be, that we are to lose you\xe2\x80\x94just as\r\nI begin to know you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! as to all that, of course nothing can be thought of yet. I am here\r\ntill claimed by Colonel and Mrs. Campbell.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing can be actually settled yet, perhaps,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Emma,\r\nsmiling\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cbut, excuse me, it must be thought of.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe smile was returned as Jane answered,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are very right; it has been thought of. And I will own to you, (I\r\nam sure it will be safe), that so far as our living with Mr. Churchill\r\nat Enscombe, it is settled. There must be three months, at least, of\r\ndeep mourning; but when they are over, I imagine there will be nothing\r\nmore to wait for.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you, thank you.\xe2\x80\x94This is just what I wanted to be assured of.\xe2\x80\x94Oh!\r\nif you knew how much I love every thing that is decided and\r\nopen!\xe2\x80\x94Good-bye, good-bye.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XVII\r\n\r\n\r\nMrs. Weston\xe2\x80\x99s friends were all made happy by her safety; and if the\r\nsatisfaction of her well-doing could be increased to Emma, it was by\r\nknowing her to be the mother of a little girl. She had been decided in\r\nwishing for a Miss Weston. She would not acknowledge that it was with\r\nany view of making a match for her, hereafter, with either of\r\nIsabella\xe2\x80\x99s sons; but she was convinced that a daughter would suit both\r\nfather and mother best. It would be a great comfort to Mr. Weston, as\r\nhe grew older\xe2\x80\x94and even Mr. Weston might be growing older ten years\r\nhence\xe2\x80\x94to have his fireside enlivened by the sports and the nonsense,\r\nthe freaks and the fancies of a child never banished from home; and\r\nMrs. Weston\xe2\x80\x94no one could doubt that a daughter would be most to her;\r\nand it would be quite a pity that any one who so well knew how to\r\nteach, should not have their powers in exercise again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe has had the advantage, you know, of practising on me,\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\ncontinued\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9clike La Baronne d\xe2\x80\x99Almane on La Comtesse d\xe2\x80\x99Ostalis, in Madame\r\nde Genlis\xe2\x80\x99 Adelaide and Theodore, and we shall now see her own little\r\nAdelaide educated on a more perfect plan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mr. Knightley, \xe2\x80\x9cshe will indulge her even more than\r\nshe did you, and believe that she does not indulge her at all. It will\r\nbe the only difference.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor child!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Emma; \xe2\x80\x9cat that rate, what will become of her?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing very bad.\xe2\x80\x94The fate of thousands. She will be disagreeable in\r\ninfancy, and correct herself as she grows older. I am losing all my\r\nbitterness against spoilt children, my dearest Emma. I, who am owing\r\nall my happiness to _you_, would not it be horrible ingratitude in me\r\nto be severe on them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEmma laughed, and replied: \xe2\x80\x9cBut I had the assistance of all your\r\nendeavours to counteract the indulgence of other people. I doubt\r\nwhether my own sense would have corrected me without it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you?\xe2\x80\x94I have no doubt. Nature gave you understanding:\xe2\x80\x94Miss Taylor\r\ngave you principles. You must have done well. My interference was quite\r\nas likely to do harm as good. It was very natural for you to say, what\r\nright has he to lecture me?\xe2\x80\x94and I am afraid very natural for you to\r\nfeel that it was done in a disagreeable manner. I do not believe I did\r\nyou any good. The good was all to myself, by making you an object of\r\nthe tenderest affection to me. I could not think about you so much\r\nwithout doating on you, faults and all; and by dint of fancying so many\r\nerrors, have been in love with you ever since you were thirteen at\r\nleast.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am sure you were of use to me,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Emma. \xe2\x80\x9cI was very often\r\ninfluenced rightly by you\xe2\x80\x94oftener than I would own at the time. I am\r\nvery sure you did me good. And if poor little Anna Weston is to be\r\nspoiled, it will be the greatest humanity in you to do as much for her\r\nas you have done for me, except falling in love with her when she is\r\nthirteen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow often, when you were a girl, have you said to me, with one of your\r\nsaucy looks\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Mr. Knightley, I am going to do so-and-so; papa says I\r\nmay, or I have Miss Taylor\xe2\x80\x99s leave\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94something which, you knew, I did\r\nnot approve. In such cases my interference was giving you two bad\r\nfeelings instead of one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat an amiable creature I was!\xe2\x80\x94No wonder you should hold my speeches\r\nin such affectionate remembrance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Mr. Knightley.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94You always called me, \xe2\x80\x98Mr. Knightley;\xe2\x80\x99 and, from\r\nhabit, it has not so very formal a sound.\xe2\x80\x94And yet it is formal. I want\r\nyou to call me something else, but I do not know what.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI remember once calling you \xe2\x80\x98George,\xe2\x80\x99 in one of my amiable fits, about\r\nten years ago. I did it because I thought it would offend you; but, as\r\nyou made no objection, I never did it again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd cannot you call me \xe2\x80\x98George\xe2\x80\x99 now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cImpossible!\xe2\x80\x94I never can call you any thing but \xe2\x80\x98Mr. Knightley.\xe2\x80\x99 I will\r\nnot promise even to equal the elegant terseness of Mrs. Elton, by\r\ncalling you Mr. K.\xe2\x80\x94But I will promise,\xe2\x80\x9d she added presently, laughing\r\nand blushing\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI will promise to call you once by your Christian name. I\r\ndo not say when, but perhaps you may guess where;\xe2\x80\x94in the building in\r\nwhich N. takes M. for better, for worse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEmma grieved that she could not be more openly just to one important\r\nservice which his better sense would have rendered her, to the advice\r\nwhich would have saved her from the worst of all her womanly\r\nfollies\xe2\x80\x94her wilful intimacy with Harriet Smith; but it was too tender a\r\nsubject.\xe2\x80\x94She could not enter on it.\xe2\x80\x94Harriet was very seldom mentioned\r\nbetween them. This, on his side, might merely proceed from her not\r\nbeing thought of; but Emma was rather inclined to attribute it to\r\ndelicacy, and a suspicion, from some appearances, that their friendship\r\nwere declining. She was aware herself, that, parting under any other\r\ncircumstances, they certainly should have corresponded more, and that\r\nher intelligence would not have rested, as it now almost wholly did, on\r\nIsabella\xe2\x80\x99s letters. He might observe that it was so. The pain of being\r\nobliged to practise concealment towards him, was very little inferior\r\nto the pain of having made Harriet unhappy.\r\n\r\nIsabella sent quite as good an account of her visitor as could be\r\nexpected; on her first arrival she had thought her out of spirits,\r\nwhich appeared perfectly natural, as there was a dentist to be\r\nconsulted; but, since that business had been over, she did not appear\r\nto find Harriet different from what she had known her before.\xe2\x80\x94Isabella,\r\nto be sure, was no very quick observer; yet if Harriet had not been\r\nequal to playing with the children, it would not have escaped her.\r\nEmma\xe2\x80\x99s comforts and hopes were most agreeably carried on, by Harriet\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbeing to stay longer; her fortnight was likely to be a month at least.\r\nMr. and Mrs. John Knightley were to come down in August, and she was\r\ninvited to remain till they could bring her back.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJohn does not even mention your friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Knightley. \xe2\x80\x9cHere is\r\nhis answer, if you like to see it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was the answer to the communication of his intended marriage. Emma\r\naccepted it with a very eager hand, with an impatience all alive to\r\nknow what he would say about it, and not at all checked by hearing that\r\nher friend was unmentioned.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJohn enters like a brother into my happiness,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Mr.\r\nKnightley, \xe2\x80\x9cbut he is no complimenter; and though I well know him to\r\nhave, likewise, a most brotherly affection for you, he is so far from\r\nmaking flourishes, that any other young woman might think him rather\r\ncool in her praise. But I am not afraid of your seeing what he writes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe writes like a sensible man,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Emma, when she had read the\r\nletter. \xe2\x80\x9cI honour his sincerity. It is very plain that he considers the\r\ngood fortune of the engagement as all on my side, but that he is not\r\nwithout hope of my growing, in time, as worthy of your affection, as\r\nyou think me already. Had he said any thing to bear a different\r\nconstruction, I should not have believed him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy Emma, he means no such thing. He only means\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe and I should differ very little in our estimation of the two,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ninterrupted she, with a sort of serious smile\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cmuch less, perhaps, than\r\nhe is aware of, if we could enter without ceremony or reserve on the\r\nsubject.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEmma, my dear Emma\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d she cried with more thorough gaiety, \xe2\x80\x9cif you fancy your brother\r\ndoes not do me justice, only wait till my dear father is in the secret,\r\nand hear his opinion. Depend upon it, he will be much farther from\r\ndoing _you_ justice. He will think all the happiness, all the\r\nadvantage, on your side of the question; all the merit on mine. I wish\r\nI may not sink into \xe2\x80\x98poor Emma\xe2\x80\x99 with him at once.\xe2\x80\x94His tender compassion\r\ntowards oppressed worth can go no farther.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, \xe2\x80\x9cI wish your father might be half as easily convinced\r\nas John will be, of our having every right that equal worth can give,\r\nto be happy together. I am amused by one part of John\xe2\x80\x99s letter\xe2\x80\x94did you\r\nnotice it?\xe2\x80\x94where he says, that my information did not take him wholly\r\nby surprize, that he was rather in expectation of hearing something of\r\nthe kind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I understand your brother, he only means so far as your having some\r\nthoughts of marrying. He had no idea of me. He seems perfectly\r\nunprepared for that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes\xe2\x80\x94but I am amused that he should have seen so far into my\r\nfeelings. What has he been judging by?\xe2\x80\x94I am not conscious of any\r\ndifference in my spirits or conversation that could prepare him at this\r\ntime for my marrying any more than at another.\xe2\x80\x94But it was so, I\r\nsuppose. I dare say there was a difference when I was staying with them\r\nthe other day. I believe I did not play with the children quite so much\r\nas usual. I remember one evening the poor boys saying, \xe2\x80\x98Uncle seems\r\nalways tired now.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe time was coming when the news must spread farther, and other\r\npersons\xe2\x80\x99 reception of it tried. As soon as Mrs. Weston was sufficiently\r\nrecovered to admit Mr. Woodhouse\xe2\x80\x99s visits, Emma having it in view that\r\nher gentle reasonings should be employed in the cause, resolved first\r\nto announce it at home, and then at Randalls.\xe2\x80\x94But how to break it to\r\nher father at last!\xe2\x80\x94She had bound herself to do it, in such an hour of\r\nMr. Knightley\xe2\x80\x99s absence, or when it came to the point her heart would\r\nhave failed her, and she must have put it off; but Mr. Knightley was to\r\ncome at such a time, and follow up the beginning she was to make.\xe2\x80\x94She\r\nwas forced to speak, and to speak cheerfully too. She must not make it\r\na more decided subject of misery to him, by a melancholy tone herself.\r\nShe must not appear to think it a misfortune.\xe2\x80\x94With all the spirits she\r\ncould command, she prepared him first for something strange, and then,\r\nin a few words, said, that if his consent and approbation could be\r\nobtained\xe2\x80\x94which, she trusted, would be attended with no difficulty,\r\nsince it was a plan to promote the happiness of all\xe2\x80\x94she and Mr.\r\nKnightley meant to marry; by which means Hartfield would receive the\r\nconstant addition of that person\xe2\x80\x99s company whom she knew he loved, next\r\nto his daughters and Mrs. Weston, best in the world.\r\n\r\nPoor man!\xe2\x80\x94it was at first a considerable shock to him, and he tried\r\nearnestly to dissuade her from it. She was reminded, more than once, of\r\nhaving always said she would never marry, and assured that it would be\r\na great deal better for her to remain single; and told of poor\r\nIsabella, and poor Miss Taylor.\xe2\x80\x94But it would not do. Emma hung about\r\nhim affectionately, and smiled, and said it must be so; and that he\r\nmust not class her with Isabella and Mrs. Weston, whose marriages\r\ntaking them from Hartfield, had, indeed, made a melancholy change: but\r\nshe was not going from Hartfield; she should be always there; she was\r\nintroducing no change in their numbers or their comforts but for the\r\nbetter; and she was very sure that he would be a great deal the happier\r\nfor having Mr. Knightley always at hand, when he were once got used to\r\nthe idea.\xe2\x80\x94Did he not love Mr. Knightley very much?\xe2\x80\x94He would not deny\r\nthat he did, she was sure.\xe2\x80\x94Whom did he ever want to consult on business\r\nbut Mr. Knightley?\xe2\x80\x94Who was so useful to him, who so ready to write his\r\nletters, who so glad to assist him?\xe2\x80\x94Who so cheerful, so attentive, so\r\nattached to him?\xe2\x80\x94Would not he like to have him always on the spot?\xe2\x80\x94Yes.\r\nThat was all very true. Mr. Knightley could not be there too often; he\r\nshould be glad to see him every day;\xe2\x80\x94but they did see him every day as\r\nit was.\xe2\x80\x94Why could not they go on as they had done?\r\n\r\nMr. Woodhouse could not be soon reconciled; but the worst was overcome,\r\nthe idea was given; time and continual repetition must do the rest.\xe2\x80\x94To\r\nEmma\xe2\x80\x99s entreaties and assurances succeeded Mr. Knightley\xe2\x80\x99s, whose fond\r\npraise of her gave the subject even a kind of welcome; and he was soon\r\nused to be talked to by each, on every fair occasion.\xe2\x80\x94They had all the\r\nassistance which Isabella could give, by letters of the strongest\r\napprobation; and Mrs. Weston was ready, on the first meeting, to\r\nconsider the subject in the most serviceable light\xe2\x80\x94first, as a settled,\r\nand, secondly, as a good one\xe2\x80\x94well aware of the nearly equal importance\r\nof the two recommendations to Mr. Woodhouse\xe2\x80\x99s mind.\xe2\x80\x94It was agreed upon,\r\nas what was to be; and every body by whom he was used to be guided\r\nassuring him that it would be for his happiness; and having some\r\nfeelings himself which almost admitted it, he began to think that some\r\ntime or other\xe2\x80\x94in another year or two, perhaps\xe2\x80\x94it might not be so very\r\nbad if the marriage did take place.\r\n\r\nMrs. Weston was acting no part, feigning no feelings in all that she\r\nsaid to him in favour of the event.\xe2\x80\x94She had been extremely surprized,\r\nnever more so, than when Emma first opened the affair to her; but she\r\nsaw in it only increase of happiness to all, and had no scruple in\r\nurging him to the utmost.\xe2\x80\x94She had such a regard for Mr. Knightley, as\r\nto think he deserved even her dearest Emma; and it was in every respect\r\nso proper, suitable, and unexceptionable a connexion, and in one\r\nrespect, one point of the highest importance, so peculiarly eligible,\r\nso singularly fortunate, that now it seemed as if Emma could not safely\r\nhave attached herself to any other creature, and that she had herself\r\nbeen the stupidest of beings in not having thought of it, and wished it\r\nlong ago.\xe2\x80\x94How very few of those men in a rank of life to address Emma\r\nwould have renounced their own home for Hartfield! And who but Mr.\r\nKnightley could know and bear with Mr. Woodhouse, so as to make such an\r\narrangement desirable!\xe2\x80\x94The difficulty of disposing of poor Mr.\r\nWoodhouse had been always felt in her husband\xe2\x80\x99s plans and her own, for\r\na marriage between Frank and Emma. How to settle the claims of Enscombe\r\nand Hartfield had been a continual impediment\xe2\x80\x94less acknowledged by Mr.\r\nWeston than by herself\xe2\x80\x94but even he had never been able to finish the\r\nsubject better than by saying\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cThose matters will take care of\r\nthemselves; the young people will find a way.\xe2\x80\x9d But here there was\r\nnothing to be shifted off in a wild speculation on the future. It was\r\nall right, all open, all equal. No sacrifice on any side worth the\r\nname. It was a union of the highest promise of felicity in itself, and\r\nwithout one real, rational difficulty to oppose or delay it.\r\n\r\nMrs. Weston, with her baby on her knee, indulging in such reflections\r\nas these, was one of the happiest women in the world. If any thing\r\ncould increase her delight, it was perceiving that the baby would soon\r\nhave outgrown its first set of caps.\r\n\r\nThe news was universally a surprize wherever it spread; and Mr. Weston\r\nhad his five minutes share of it; but five minutes were enough to\r\nfamiliarise the idea to his quickness of mind.\xe2\x80\x94He saw the advantages of\r\nthe match, and rejoiced in them with all the constancy of his wife; but\r\nthe wonder of it was very soon nothing; and by the end of an hour he\r\nwas not far from believing that he had always foreseen it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is to be a secret, I conclude,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cThese matters are always\r\na secret, till it is found out that every body knows them. Only let me\r\nbe told when I may speak out.\xe2\x80\x94I wonder whether Jane has any suspicion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe went to Highbury the next morning, and satisfied himself on that\r\npoint. He told her the news. Was not she like a daughter, his eldest\r\ndaughter?\xe2\x80\x94he must tell her; and Miss Bates being present, it passed, of\r\ncourse, to Mrs. Cole, Mrs. Perry, and Mrs. Elton, immediately\r\nafterwards. It was no more than the principals were prepared for; they\r\nhad calculated from the time of its being known at Randalls, how soon\r\nit would be over Highbury; and were thinking of themselves, as the\r\nevening wonder in many a family circle, with great sagacity.\r\n\r\nIn general, it was a very well approved match. Some might think him,\r\nand others might think her, the most in luck. One set might recommend\r\ntheir all removing to Donwell, and leaving Hartfield for the John\r\nKnightleys; and another might predict disagreements among their\r\nservants; but yet, upon the whole, there was no serious objection\r\nraised, except in one habitation, the Vicarage.\xe2\x80\x94There, the surprize was\r\nnot softened by any satisfaction. Mr. Elton cared little about it,\r\ncompared with his wife; he only hoped \xe2\x80\x9cthe young lady\xe2\x80\x99s pride would now\r\nbe contented;\xe2\x80\x9d and supposed \xe2\x80\x9cshe had always meant to catch Knightley if\r\nshe could;\xe2\x80\x9d and, on the point of living at Hartfield, could daringly\r\nexclaim, \xe2\x80\x9cRather he than I!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94But Mrs. Elton was very much discomposed\r\nindeed.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cPoor Knightley! poor fellow!\xe2\x80\x94sad business for him.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94She was\r\nextremely concerned; for, though very eccentric, he had a thousand good\r\nqualities.\xe2\x80\x94How could he be so taken in?\xe2\x80\x94Did not think him at all in\r\nlove\xe2\x80\x94not in the least.\xe2\x80\x94Poor Knightley!\xe2\x80\x94There would be an end of all\r\npleasant intercourse with him.\xe2\x80\x94How happy he had been to come and dine\r\nwith them whenever they asked him! But that would be all over now.\xe2\x80\x94Poor\r\nfellow!\xe2\x80\x94No more exploring parties to Donwell made for _her_. Oh! no;\r\nthere would be a Mrs. Knightley to throw cold water on every\r\nthing.\xe2\x80\x94Extremely disagreeable! But she was not at all sorry that she\r\nhad abused the housekeeper the other day.\xe2\x80\x94Shocking plan, living\r\ntogether. It would never do. She knew a family near Maple Grove who had\r\ntried it, and been obliged to separate before the end of the first\r\nquarter.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XVIII\r\n\r\n\r\nTime passed on. A few more to-morrows, and the party from London would\r\nbe arriving. It was an alarming change; and Emma was thinking of it one\r\nmorning, as what must bring a great deal to agitate and grieve her,\r\nwhen Mr. Knightley came in, and distressing thoughts were put by. After\r\nthe first chat of pleasure he was silent; and then, in a graver tone,\r\nbegan with,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have something to tell you, Emma; some news.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood or bad?\xe2\x80\x9d said she, quickly, looking up in his face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not know which it ought to be called.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! good I am sure.\xe2\x80\x94I see it in your countenance. You are trying not\r\nto smile.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am afraid,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, composing his features, \xe2\x80\x9cI am very much afraid,\r\nmy dear Emma, that you will not smile when you hear it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed! but why so?\xe2\x80\x94I can hardly imagine that any thing which pleases\r\nor amuses you, should not please and amuse me too.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is one subject,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied, \xe2\x80\x9cI hope but one, on which we do not\r\nthink alike.\xe2\x80\x9d He paused a moment, again smiling, with his eyes fixed on\r\nher face. \xe2\x80\x9cDoes nothing occur to you?\xe2\x80\x94Do not you recollect?\xe2\x80\x94Harriet\r\nSmith.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHer cheeks flushed at the name, and she felt afraid of something,\r\nthough she knew not what.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you heard from her yourself this morning?\xe2\x80\x9d cried he. \xe2\x80\x9cYou have, I\r\nbelieve, and know the whole.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I have not; I know nothing; pray tell me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are prepared for the worst, I see\xe2\x80\x94and very bad it is. Harriet\r\nSmith marries Robert Martin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEmma gave a start, which did not seem like being prepared\xe2\x80\x94and her eyes,\r\nin eager gaze, said, \xe2\x80\x9cNo, this is impossible!\xe2\x80\x9d but her lips were\r\nclosed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is so, indeed,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Mr. Knightley; \xe2\x80\x9cI have it from Robert\r\nMartin himself. He left me not half an hour ago.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe was still looking at him with the most speaking amazement.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou like it, my Emma, as little as I feared.\xe2\x80\x94I wish our opinions were\r\nthe same. But in time they will. Time, you may be sure, will make one\r\nor the other of us think differently; and, in the meanwhile, we need\r\nnot talk much on the subject.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou mistake me, you quite mistake me,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied, exerting herself.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not that such a circumstance would now make me unhappy, but I\r\ncannot believe it. It seems an impossibility!\xe2\x80\x94You cannot mean to say,\r\nthat Harriet Smith has accepted Robert Martin. You cannot mean that he\r\nhas even proposed to her again\xe2\x80\x94yet. You only mean, that he intends it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mean that he has done it,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Mr. Knightley, with smiling but\r\ndetermined decision, \xe2\x80\x9cand been accepted.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood God!\xe2\x80\x9d she cried.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cWell!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Then having recourse to her workbasket,\r\nin excuse for leaning down her face, and concealing all the exquisite\r\nfeelings of delight and entertainment which she knew she must be\r\nexpressing, she added, \xe2\x80\x9cWell, now tell me every thing; make this\r\nintelligible to me. How, where, when?\xe2\x80\x94Let me know it all. I never was\r\nmore surprized\xe2\x80\x94but it does not make me unhappy, I assure you.\xe2\x80\x94How\xe2\x80\x94how\r\nhas it been possible?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a very simple story. He went to town on business three days ago,\r\nand I got him to take charge of some papers which I was wanting to send\r\nto John.\xe2\x80\x94He delivered these papers to John, at his chambers, and was\r\nasked by him to join their party the same evening to Astley\xe2\x80\x99s. They\r\nwere going to take the two eldest boys to Astley\xe2\x80\x99s. The party was to be\r\nour brother and sister, Henry, John\xe2\x80\x94and Miss Smith. My friend Robert\r\ncould not resist. They called for him in their way; were all extremely\r\namused; and my brother asked him to dine with them the next day\xe2\x80\x94which\r\nhe did\xe2\x80\x94and in the course of that visit (as I understand) he found an\r\nopportunity of speaking to Harriet; and certainly did not speak in\r\nvain.\xe2\x80\x94She made him, by her acceptance, as happy even as he is\r\ndeserving. He came down by yesterday\xe2\x80\x99s coach, and was with me this\r\nmorning immediately after breakfast, to report his proceedings, first\r\non my affairs, and then on his own. This is all that I can relate of\r\nthe how, where, and when. Your friend Harriet will make a much longer\r\nhistory when you see her.\xe2\x80\x94She will give you all the minute particulars,\r\nwhich only woman\xe2\x80\x99s language can make interesting.\xe2\x80\x94In our communications\r\nwe deal only in the great.\xe2\x80\x94However, I must say, that Robert Martin\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nheart seemed for _him_, and to _me_, very overflowing; and that he did\r\nmention, without its being much to the purpose, that on quitting their\r\nbox at Astley\xe2\x80\x99s, my brother took charge of Mrs. John Knightley and\r\nlittle John, and he followed with Miss Smith and Henry; and that at one\r\ntime they were in such a crowd, as to make Miss Smith rather uneasy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe stopped.\xe2\x80\x94Emma dared not attempt any immediate reply. To speak, she\r\nwas sure would be to betray a most unreasonable degree of happiness.\r\nShe must wait a moment, or he would think her mad. Her silence\r\ndisturbed him; and after observing her a little while, he added,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEmma, my love, you said that this circumstance would not now make you\r\nunhappy; but I am afraid it gives you more pain than you expected. His\r\nsituation is an evil\xe2\x80\x94but you must consider it as what satisfies your\r\nfriend; and I will answer for your thinking better and better of him as\r\nyou know him more. His good sense and good principles would delight\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x94As far as the man is concerned, you could not wish your friend in\r\nbetter hands. His rank in society I would alter if I could, which is\r\nsaying a great deal I assure you, Emma.\xe2\x80\x94You laugh at me about William\r\nLarkins; but I could quite as ill spare Robert Martin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe wanted her to look up and smile; and having now brought herself not\r\nto smile too broadly\xe2\x80\x94she did\xe2\x80\x94cheerfully answering,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou need not be at any pains to reconcile me to the match. I think\r\nHarriet is doing extremely well. _Her_ connexions may be worse than\r\n_his_. In respectability of character, there can be no doubt that they\r\nare. I have been silent from surprize merely, excessive surprize. You\r\ncannot imagine how suddenly it has come on me! how peculiarly\r\nunprepared I was!\xe2\x80\x94for I had reason to believe her very lately more\r\ndetermined against him, much more, than she was before.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou ought to know your friend best,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mr. Knightley; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I\r\nshould say she was a good-tempered, soft-hearted girl, not likely to be\r\nvery, very determined against any young man who told her he loved her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEmma could not help laughing as she answered, \xe2\x80\x9cUpon my word, I believe\r\nyou know her quite as well as I do.\xe2\x80\x94But, Mr. Knightley, are you\r\nperfectly sure that she has absolutely and downright _accepted_ him. I\r\ncould suppose she might in time\xe2\x80\x94but can she already?\xe2\x80\x94Did not you\r\nmisunderstand him?\xe2\x80\x94You were both talking of other things; of business,\r\nshows of cattle, or new drills\xe2\x80\x94and might not you, in the confusion of\r\nso many subjects, mistake him?\xe2\x80\x94It was not Harriet\xe2\x80\x99s hand that he was\r\ncertain of\xe2\x80\x94it was the dimensions of some famous ox.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe contrast between the countenance and air of Mr. Knightley and\r\nRobert Martin was, at this moment, so strong to Emma\xe2\x80\x99s feelings, and so\r\nstrong was the recollection of all that had so recently passed on\r\nHarriet\xe2\x80\x99s side, so fresh the sound of those words, spoken with such\r\nemphasis, \xe2\x80\x9cNo, I hope I know better than to think of Robert Martin,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nthat she was really expecting the intelligence to prove, in some\r\nmeasure, premature. It could not be otherwise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you dare say this?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mr. Knightley. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you dare to suppose me\r\nso great a blockhead, as not to know what a man is talking of?\xe2\x80\x94What do\r\nyou deserve?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! I always deserve the best treatment, because I never put up with\r\nany other; and, therefore, you must give me a plain, direct answer. Are\r\nyou quite sure that you understand the terms on which Mr. Martin and\r\nHarriet now are?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am quite sure,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied, speaking very distinctly, \xe2\x80\x9cthat he told\r\nme she had accepted him; and that there was no obscurity, nothing\r\ndoubtful, in the words he used; and I think I can give you a proof that\r\nit must be so. He asked my opinion as to what he was now to do. He knew\r\nof no one but Mrs. Goddard to whom he could apply for information of\r\nher relations or friends. Could I mention any thing more fit to be\r\ndone, than to go to Mrs. Goddard? I assured him that I could not. Then,\r\nhe said, he would endeavour to see her in the course of this day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am perfectly satisfied,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Emma, with the brightest smiles,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cand most sincerely wish them happy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are materially changed since we talked on this subject before.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope so\xe2\x80\x94for at that time I was a fool.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I am changed also; for I am now very willing to grant you all\r\nHarriet\xe2\x80\x99s good qualities. I have taken some pains for your sake, and\r\nfor Robert Martin\xe2\x80\x99s sake, (whom I have always had reason to believe as\r\nmuch in love with her as ever,) to get acquainted with her. I have\r\noften talked to her a good deal. You must have seen that I did.\r\nSometimes, indeed, I have thought you were half suspecting me of\r\npleading poor Martin\xe2\x80\x99s cause, which was never the case; but, from all\r\nmy observations, I am convinced of her being an artless, amiable girl,\r\nwith very good notions, very seriously good principles, and placing her\r\nhappiness in the affections and utility of domestic life.\xe2\x80\x94Much of this,\r\nI have no doubt, she may thank you for.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMe!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Emma, shaking her head.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cAh! poor Harriet!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe checked herself, however, and submitted quietly to a little more\r\npraise than she deserved.\r\n\r\nTheir conversation was soon afterwards closed by the entrance of her\r\nfather. She was not sorry. She wanted to be alone. Her mind was in a\r\nstate of flutter and wonder, which made it impossible for her to be\r\ncollected. She was in dancing, singing, exclaiming spirits; and till\r\nshe had moved about, and talked to herself, and laughed and reflected,\r\nshe could be fit for nothing rational.\r\n\r\nHer father\xe2\x80\x99s business was to announce James\xe2\x80\x99s being gone out to put the\r\nhorses to, preparatory to their now daily drive to Randalls; and she\r\nhad, therefore, an immediate excuse for disappearing.\r\n\r\nThe joy, the gratitude, the exquisite delight of her sensations may be\r\nimagined. The sole grievance and alloy thus removed in the prospect of\r\nHarriet\xe2\x80\x99s welfare, she was really in danger of becoming too happy for\r\nsecurity.\xe2\x80\x94What had she to wish for? Nothing, but to grow more worthy of\r\nhim, whose intentions and judgment had been ever so superior to her\r\nown. Nothing, but that the lessons of her past folly might teach her\r\nhumility and circumspection in future.\r\n\r\nSerious she was, very serious in her thankfulness, and in her\r\nresolutions; and yet there was no preventing a laugh, sometimes in the\r\nvery midst of them. She must laugh at such a close! Such an end of the\r\ndoleful disappointment of five weeks back! Such a heart\xe2\x80\x94such a Harriet!\r\n\r\nNow there would be pleasure in her returning\xe2\x80\x94Every thing would be a\r\npleasure. It would be a great pleasure to know Robert Martin.\r\n\r\nHigh in the rank of her most serious and heartfelt felicities, was the\r\nreflection that all necessity of concealment from Mr. Knightley would\r\nsoon be over. The disguise, equivocation, mystery, so hateful to her to\r\npractise, might soon be over. She could now look forward to giving him\r\nthat full and perfect confidence which her disposition was most ready\r\nto welcome as a duty.\r\n\r\nIn the gayest and happiest spirits she set forward with her father; not\r\nalways listening, but always agreeing to what he said; and, whether in\r\nspeech or silence, conniving at the comfortable persuasion of his being\r\nobliged to go to Randalls every day, or poor Mrs. Weston would be\r\ndisappointed.\r\n\r\nThey arrived.\xe2\x80\x94Mrs. Weston was alone in the drawing-room:\xe2\x80\x94but hardly had\r\nthey been told of the baby, and Mr. Woodhouse received the thanks for\r\ncoming, which he asked for, when a glimpse was caught through the\r\nblind, of two figures passing near the window.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is Frank and Miss Fairfax,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Weston. \xe2\x80\x9cI was just going to\r\ntell you of our agreeable surprize in seeing him arrive this morning.\r\nHe stays till to-morrow, and Miss Fairfax has been persuaded to spend\r\nthe day with us.\xe2\x80\x94They are coming in, I hope.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn half a minute they were in the room. Emma was extremely glad to see\r\nhim\xe2\x80\x94but there was a degree of confusion\xe2\x80\x94a number of embarrassing\r\nrecollections on each side. They met readily and smiling, but with a\r\nconsciousness which at first allowed little to be said; and having all\r\nsat down again, there was for some time such a blank in the circle,\r\nthat Emma began to doubt whether the wish now indulged, which she had\r\nlong felt, of seeing Frank Churchill once more, and of seeing him with\r\nJane, would yield its proportion of pleasure. When Mr. Weston joined\r\nthe party, however, and when the baby was fetched, there was no longer\r\na want of subject or animation\xe2\x80\x94or of courage and opportunity for Frank\r\nChurchill to draw near her and say,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have to thank you, Miss Woodhouse, for a very kind forgiving message\r\nin one of Mrs. Weston\xe2\x80\x99s letters. I hope time has not made you less\r\nwilling to pardon. I hope you do not retract what you then said.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, indeed,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Emma, most happy to begin, \xe2\x80\x9cnot in the least. I am\r\nparticularly glad to see and shake hands with you\xe2\x80\x94and to give you joy\r\nin person.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe thanked her with all his heart, and continued some time to speak\r\nwith serious feeling of his gratitude and happiness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs not she looking well?\xe2\x80\x9d said he, turning his eyes towards Jane.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBetter than she ever used to do?\xe2\x80\x94You see how my father and Mrs. Weston\r\ndoat upon her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut his spirits were soon rising again, and with laughing eyes, after\r\nmentioning the expected return of the Campbells, he named the name of\r\nDixon.\xe2\x80\x94Emma blushed, and forbade its being pronounced in her hearing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can never think of it,\xe2\x80\x9d she cried, \xe2\x80\x9cwithout extreme shame.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe shame,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered, \xe2\x80\x9cis all mine, or ought to be. But is it\r\npossible that you had no suspicion?\xe2\x80\x94I mean of late. Early, I know, you\r\nhad none.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never had the smallest, I assure you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat appears quite wonderful. I was once very near\xe2\x80\x94and I wish I had\xe2\x80\x94it\r\nwould have been better. But though I was always doing wrong things,\r\nthey were very bad wrong things, and such as did me no service.\xe2\x80\x94It\r\nwould have been a much better transgression had I broken the bond of\r\nsecrecy and told you every thing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not now worth a regret,\xe2\x80\x9d said Emma.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have some hope,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed he, \xe2\x80\x9cof my uncle\xe2\x80\x99s being persuaded to pay a\r\nvisit at Randalls; he wants to be introduced to her. When the Campbells\r\nare returned, we shall meet them in London, and continue there, I\r\ntrust, till we may carry her northward.\xe2\x80\x94But now, I am at such a\r\ndistance from her\xe2\x80\x94is not it hard, Miss Woodhouse?\xe2\x80\x94Till this morning, we\r\nhave not once met since the day of reconciliation.
