Do not you pity me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEmma spoke her pity so very kindly, that with a sudden accession of gay\r\nthought, he cried,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! by the bye,\xe2\x80\x9d then sinking his voice, and looking demure for the\r\nmoment\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI hope Mr. Knightley is well?\xe2\x80\x9d He paused.\xe2\x80\x94She coloured and\r\nlaughed.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI know you saw my letter, and think you may remember my wish\r\nin your favour. Let me return your congratulations.\xe2\x80\x94I assure you that I\r\nhave heard the news with the warmest interest and satisfaction.\xe2\x80\x94He is a\r\nman whom I cannot presume to praise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEmma was delighted, and only wanted him to go on in the same style; but\r\nhis mind was the next moment in his own concerns and with his own Jane,\r\nand his next words were,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you ever see such a skin?\xe2\x80\x94such smoothness! such delicacy!\xe2\x80\x94and yet\r\nwithout being actually fair.\xe2\x80\x94One cannot call her fair. It is a most\r\nuncommon complexion, with her dark eye-lashes and hair\xe2\x80\x94a most\r\ndistinguishing complexion! So peculiarly the lady in it.\xe2\x80\x94Just colour\r\nenough for beauty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have always admired her complexion,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Emma, archly; \xe2\x80\x9cbut do\r\nnot I remember the time when you found fault with her for being so\r\npale?\xe2\x80\x94When we first began to talk of her.\xe2\x80\x94Have you quite forgotten?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! no\xe2\x80\x94what an impudent dog I was!\xe2\x80\x94How could I dare\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut he laughed so heartily at the recollection, that Emma could not\r\nhelp saying,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do suspect that in the midst of your perplexities at that time, you\r\nhad very great amusement in tricking us all.\xe2\x80\x94I am sure you had.\xe2\x80\x94I am\r\nsure it was a consolation to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! no, no, no\xe2\x80\x94how can you suspect me of such a thing? I was the most\r\nmiserable wretch!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot quite so miserable as to be insensible to mirth. I am sure it was\r\na source of high entertainment to you, to feel that you were taking us\r\nall in.\xe2\x80\x94Perhaps I am the readier to suspect, because, to tell you the\r\ntruth, I think it might have been some amusement to myself in the same\r\nsituation. I think there is a little likeness between us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe bowed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf not in our dispositions,\xe2\x80\x9d she presently added, with a look of true\r\nsensibility, \xe2\x80\x9cthere is a likeness in our destiny; the destiny which\r\nbids fair to connect us with two characters so much superior to our\r\nown.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue, true,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered, warmly. \xe2\x80\x9cNo, not true on your side. You can\r\nhave no superior, but most true on mine.\xe2\x80\x94She is a complete angel. Look\r\nat her. Is not she an angel in every gesture? Observe the turn of her\r\nthroat. Observe her eyes, as she is looking up at my father.\xe2\x80\x94You will\r\nbe glad to hear (inclining his head, and whispering seriously) that my\r\nuncle means to give her all my aunt\xe2\x80\x99s jewels. They are to be new set. I\r\nam resolved to have some in an ornament for the head. Will not it be\r\nbeautiful in her dark hair?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery beautiful, indeed,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Emma; and she spoke so kindly, that\r\nhe gratefully burst out,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow delighted I am to see you again! and to see you in such excellent\r\nlooks!\xe2\x80\x94I would not have missed this meeting for the world. I should\r\ncertainly have called at Hartfield, had you failed to come.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe others had been talking of the child, Mrs. Weston giving an account\r\nof a little alarm she had been under, the evening before, from the\r\ninfant\xe2\x80\x99s appearing not quite well. She believed she had been foolish,\r\nbut it had alarmed her, and she had been within half a minute of\r\nsending for Mr. Perry. Perhaps she ought to be ashamed, but Mr. Weston\r\nhad been almost as uneasy as herself.\xe2\x80\x94In ten minutes, however, the\r\nchild had been perfectly well again. This was her history; and\r\nparticularly interesting it was to Mr. Woodhouse, who commended her\r\nvery much for thinking of sending for Perry, and only regretted that\r\nshe had not done it. \xe2\x80\x9cShe should always send for Perry, if the child\r\nappeared in the slightest degree disordered, were it only for a moment.\r\nShe could not be too soon alarmed, nor send for Perry too often. It was\r\na pity, perhaps, that he had not come last night; for, though the child\r\nseemed well now, very well considering, it would probably have been\r\nbetter if Perry had seen it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFrank Churchill caught the name.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerry!\xe2\x80\x9d said he to Emma, and trying, as he spoke, to catch Miss\r\nFairfax\xe2\x80\x99s eye. \xe2\x80\x9cMy friend Mr. Perry! What are they saying about Mr.\r\nPerry?\xe2\x80\x94Has he been here this morning?\xe2\x80\x94And how does he travel now?\xe2\x80\x94Has\r\nhe set up his carriage?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEmma soon recollected, and understood him; and while she joined in the\r\nlaugh, it was evident from Jane\xe2\x80\x99s countenance that she too was really\r\nhearing him, though trying to seem deaf.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuch an extraordinary dream of mine!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried. \xe2\x80\x9cI can never think of\r\nit without laughing.\xe2\x80\x94She hears us, she hears us, Miss Woodhouse. I see\r\nit in her cheek, her smile, her vain attempt to frown. Look at her. Do\r\nnot you see that, at this instant, the very passage of her own letter,\r\nwhich sent me the report, is passing under her eye\xe2\x80\x94that the whole\r\nblunder is spread before her\xe2\x80\x94that she can attend to nothing else,\r\nthough pretending to listen to the others?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJane was forced to smile completely, for a moment; and the smile partly\r\nremained as she turned towards him, and said in a conscious, low, yet\r\nsteady voice,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow you can bear such recollections, is astonishing to me!\xe2\x80\x94They _will_\r\nsometimes obtrude\xe2\x80\x94but how you can court them!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe had a great deal to say in return, and very entertainingly; but\r\nEmma\xe2\x80\x99s feelings were chiefly with Jane, in the argument; and on leaving\r\nRandalls, and falling naturally into a comparison of the two men, she\r\nfelt, that pleased as she had been to see Frank Churchill, and really\r\nregarding him as she did with friendship, she had never been more\r\nsensible of Mr. Knightley\xe2\x80\x99s high superiority of character. The\r\nhappiness of this most happy day, received its completion, in the\r\nanimated contemplation of his worth which this comparison produced.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XIX\r\n\r\n\r\nIf Emma had still, at intervals, an anxious feeling for Harriet, a\r\nmomentary doubt of its being possible for her to be really cured of her\r\nattachment to Mr. Knightley, and really able to accept another man from\r\nunbiased inclination, it was not long that she had to suffer from the\r\nrecurrence of any such uncertainty. A very few days brought the party\r\nfrom London, and she had no sooner an opportunity of being one hour\r\nalone with Harriet, than she became perfectly satisfied\xe2\x80\x94unaccountable\r\nas it was!\xe2\x80\x94that Robert Martin had thoroughly supplanted Mr. Knightley,\r\nand was now forming all her views of happiness.\r\n\r\nHarriet was a little distressed\xe2\x80\x94did look a little foolish at first: but\r\nhaving once owned that she had been presumptuous and silly, and\r\nself-deceived, before, her pain and confusion seemed to die away with\r\nthe words, and leave her without a care for the past, and with the\r\nfullest exultation in the present and future; for, as to her friend\xe2\x80\x99s\r\napprobation, Emma had instantly removed every fear of that nature, by\r\nmeeting her with the most unqualified congratulations.\xe2\x80\x94Harriet was most\r\nhappy to give every particular of the evening at Astley\xe2\x80\x99s, and the\r\ndinner the next day; she could dwell on it all with the utmost delight.\r\nBut what did such particulars explain?\xe2\x80\x94The fact was, as Emma could now\r\nacknowledge, that Harriet had always liked Robert Martin; and that his\r\ncontinuing to love her had been irresistible.\xe2\x80\x94Beyond this, it must ever\r\nbe unintelligible to Emma.\r\n\r\nThe event, however, was most joyful; and every day was giving her fresh\r\nreason for thinking so.\xe2\x80\x94Harriet\xe2\x80\x99s parentage became known. She proved to\r\nbe the daughter of a tradesman, rich enough to afford her the\r\ncomfortable maintenance which had ever been hers, and decent enough to\r\nhave always wished for concealment.\xe2\x80\x94Such was the blood of gentility\r\nwhich Emma had formerly been so ready to vouch for!\xe2\x80\x94It was likely to be\r\nas untainted, perhaps, as the blood of many a gentleman: but what a\r\nconnexion had she been preparing for Mr. Knightley\xe2\x80\x94or for the\r\nChurchills\xe2\x80\x94or even for Mr. Elton!\xe2\x80\x94The stain of illegitimacy, unbleached\r\nby nobility or wealth, would have been a stain indeed.\r\n\r\nNo objection was raised on the father\xe2\x80\x99s side; the young man was treated\r\nliberally; it was all as it should be: and as Emma became acquainted\r\nwith Robert Martin, who was now introduced at Hartfield, she fully\r\nacknowledged in him all the appearance of sense and worth which could\r\nbid fairest for her little friend. She had no doubt of Harriet\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhappiness with any good-tempered man; but with him, and in the home he\r\noffered, there would be the hope of more, of security, stability, and\r\nimprovement. She would be placed in the midst of those who loved her,\r\nand who had better sense than herself; retired enough for safety, and\r\noccupied enough for cheerfulness. She would be never led into\r\ntemptation, nor left for it to find her out. She would be respectable\r\nand happy; and Emma admitted her to be the luckiest creature in the\r\nworld, to have created so steady and persevering an affection in such a\r\nman;\xe2\x80\x94or, if not quite the luckiest, to yield only to herself.\r\n\r\nHarriet, necessarily drawn away by her engagements with the Martins,\r\nwas less and less at Hartfield; which was not to be regretted.\xe2\x80\x94The\r\nintimacy between her and Emma must sink; their friendship must change\r\ninto a calmer sort of goodwill; and, fortunately, what ought to be, and\r\nmust be, seemed already beginning, and in the most gradual, natural\r\nmanner.\r\n\r\nBefore the end of September, Emma attended Harriet to church, and saw\r\nher hand bestowed on Robert Martin with so complete a satisfaction, as\r\nno remembrances, even connected with Mr. Elton as he stood before them,\r\ncould impair.\xe2\x80\x94Perhaps, indeed, at that time she scarcely saw Mr. Elton,\r\nbut as the clergyman whose blessing at the altar might next fall on\r\nherself.\xe2\x80\x94Robert Martin and Harriet Smith, the latest couple engaged of\r\nthe three, were the first to be married.\r\n\r\nJane Fairfax had already quitted Highbury, and was restored to the\r\ncomforts of her beloved home with the Campbells.\xe2\x80\x94The Mr. Churchills\r\nwere also in town; and they were only waiting for November.\r\n\r\nThe intermediate month was the one fixed on, as far as they dared, by\r\nEmma and Mr. Knightley.\xe2\x80\x94They had determined that their marriage ought\r\nto be concluded while John and Isabella were still at Hartfield, to\r\nallow them the fortnight\xe2\x80\x99s absence in a tour to the seaside, which was\r\nthe plan.\xe2\x80\x94John and Isabella, and every other friend, were agreed in\r\napproving it. But Mr. Woodhouse\xe2\x80\x94how was Mr. Woodhouse to be induced to\r\nconsent?\xe2\x80\x94he, who had never yet alluded to their marriage but as a\r\ndistant event.\r\n\r\nWhen first sounded on the subject, he was so miserable, that they were\r\nalmost hopeless.\xe2\x80\x94A second allusion, indeed, gave less pain.\xe2\x80\x94He began to\r\nthink it was to be, and that he could not prevent it\xe2\x80\x94a very promising\r\nstep of the mind on its way to resignation. Still, however, he was not\r\nhappy. Nay, he appeared so much otherwise, that his daughter\xe2\x80\x99s courage\r\nfailed. She could not bear to see him suffering, to know him fancying\r\nhimself neglected; and though her understanding almost acquiesced in\r\nthe assurance of both the Mr. Knightleys, that when once the event were\r\nover, his distress would be soon over too, she hesitated\xe2\x80\x94she could not\r\nproceed.\r\n\r\nIn this state of suspense they were befriended, not by any sudden\r\nillumination of Mr. Woodhouse\xe2\x80\x99s mind, or any wonderful change of his\r\nnervous system, but by the operation of the same system in another\r\nway.\xe2\x80\x94Mrs. Weston\xe2\x80\x99s poultry-house was robbed one night of all her\r\nturkeys\xe2\x80\x94evidently by the ingenuity of man. Other poultry-yards in the\r\nneighbourhood also suffered.\xe2\x80\x94Pilfering was _housebreaking_ to Mr.\r\nWoodhouse\xe2\x80\x99s fears.\xe2\x80\x94He was very uneasy; and but for the sense of his\r\nson-in-law\xe2\x80\x99s protection, would have been under wretched alarm every\r\nnight of his life. The strength, resolution, and presence of mind of\r\nthe Mr. Knightleys, commanded his fullest dependence. While either of\r\nthem protected him and his, Hartfield was safe.\xe2\x80\x94But Mr. John Knightley\r\nmust be in London again by the end of the first week in November.\r\n\r\nThe result of this distress was, that, with a much more voluntary,\r\ncheerful consent than his daughter had ever presumed to hope for at the\r\nmoment, she was able to fix her wedding-day\xe2\x80\x94and Mr. Elton was called\r\non, within a month from the marriage of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Martin, to\r\njoin the hands of Mr. Knightley and Miss Woodhouse.\r\n\r\nThe wedding was very much like other weddings, where the parties have\r\nno taste for finery or parade; and Mrs. Elton, from the particulars\r\ndetailed by her husband, thought it all extremely shabby, and very\r\ninferior to her own.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cVery little white satin, very few lace veils; a\r\nmost pitiful business!\xe2\x80\x94Selina would stare when she heard of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94But,\r\nin spite of these deficiencies, the wishes, the hopes, the confidence,\r\nthe predictions of the small band of true friends who witnessed the\r\nceremony, were fully answered in the perfect happiness of the union.\r\n\r\nFINIS\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n
